talk.start.para: - I wish to know from the Minister representing the Minister for Defence : -

item.para: Whether he is aware that a trooper, returning from South Africa by thes.s. Norfolk, and suffering from appendicitis, was not allowed to be landed at Adelaide by the military doctor of that port, though the military doctor on board certified that he was in great danger?

. Whether he is aware that a certificate from Captain Cutler, of thes.s. Norfolk, is in existence to the following effect : - "The s.s. Norfolk arrived in Adelaide on Wednesday with one of the troopers suffering severely from appendicitis. (Signed) Thos. E. Cutler,

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Postmaster-General, upon notice -

item.para: Has the attention of the Postmaster-General been drawn to the evidence given before the "Free Carriage of Newspapers Commission" now sitting in New South Wales ; and, if not, will he find an opportunity to read the report of the same in the Sydney Morning Herald of the 26th July?

Is the sworn statement of Mr. W. McLachlan, Secretary to the New South Wales Railway Commissioners, true that the Postal department now pays such commissioners for the loss occasioned by the carriage of newspapers ; and is there any explanation of this state of affairs ? 3.Is it true, as stated in such evidence, that special trains are run from Sydney to southern districts so as to defeat the early delivery of Victorian mail matter and newspapers?
Has the Postmaster-General any contract with the New South Wales railways in regard to newspaper carriage ; and what are its terms ?.

Do the New South Wales railways charge Victorian newspaper proprietors different rates for carriage of newspapers than they charge New South Wales newspaper proprietors ; and, if so, what steps does the Postmaster-General propose to take in reference thereto ?

talk.start.para: - The answers to the honorable and learned member's questions are as follow : -

item.para: The attention of the Postmaster-General has been drawn to a statement of evidence in connexion with the subject referred to, as published in the Sydney Morning Herald of the 26th July. He, however, awaits the official copy of the evidence.
Mr. McLachlan'sevidence has been misunderstood ; the New South Wales Railway Commissioners are not being paid by the Postal department for any loss occasioned by the carriage of newspapers.

Special trains are. not run, but ordinary goods trains are timed to leave Sydney at an hour suitable for the conveyance of Sydney morning newspapers to the southern districts. These trains do not carry mails. The arrangement for the early despatch of these trains was made in 1887.

There is no contract now with the New South Wales Railway Commissioners for any special carriage of newspapers. A payment at the rate of £2,500 per annum was made up to the 5th August, 1901, to the Railway Commissioners for the conveyance of newspapers by all trains, but this was discontinued by the instruction of the Postmaster-General on that date.

The Deputy Postmaster-General of New South Wales has been informed by Mr. McLachlan, secretory to the New South Wales Railway Commissioners, that the commissioners propose to charge the newspaper proprietors an annual rate for the carriage of the New South Wales newspapers. The arrangement has not yet been confirmed, and the Postmaster-General is not aware of the details.

debate.para: In Committee(Considerationresumed from 1st August, vide page 14835):

quote.para: The Governor-General may authorize the payment out of the consolidated revenue fund, which is hereby appropriated for the purpose of bonuses on the manufacture in Australia after the commencement of this Act of the goods specified in the schedule to this Act according to the rates set out in the said schedule. Provided that no bonus shall be paid in respect of pig-iron, puddled bar iron, iron or steel pipes or tubes, or steel, unless the same is manufactured in works operated by a State Government.

debate.para: Upon which Mr. Kingston had moved by way of amendment -

quote.para: That all the words after the word "schedule," line 7, be omitted.

talk.start.para: - I am glad to have an opportunity to deal with this measure before the committee comes to a final decision in regard to it. For the last fifteen rather weary months we have been watching the legislative antics of my friends opposite ; but the series of gyrations connected with the measure now before us is unprecedented even in this Parliament. A Bill was introduced for the specific purpose of encouraging the manufacture of iron in Australia from Australian ore by private individuals ; but in committee an amendment was moved which said that under no circumstances should private individuals receive the encouragement proposed. When the ostensible purpose of a Bill is practically nullified in that way, the only course open to an honorable Ministry is to throw it under the table. But in connexion with this Bill very peculiar action has been taken. The Government, instead of throwing it under the table, have made inquiries from the different State Governments to ascertain if they will be good enough to accept a bribe of £250,000 for the creation of the iron industry. They have all replied that they wish to have nothing to do with such an undertaking, and are unwilling to receive the money. Now, therefore, the Bill is brought before us again, and the Government ask us to excise the proviso which was inserted in clause 3 when it was originally taken into committee. But we are not told whether the Government will stand or fall by their proposal. They intimate to the House by their action that they are of opinion that private individuals and not the States should be entrusted with the establishment of the iron industry in Australia. But if the amendment of the Minister for Trade and Custom is defeated, will they still go on with the Bill, and send to the Senate a measure, the provisions of which they disapprove We have a right to know whether our affairs are being administered under a system of responsible government or whether Ministers are to be regarded simply as a committee appointed to record the votes of the majority. If the Ministry have a policy they should stand or fall by it. I desire to know whether, in the event of their proposal upon recommittal being defeated, the Government will go on with the Bill ? We have . a right to look for an answer to that question. No two principles could be more diametrically opposed than those involved in granting bonuses to private individuals and in the offering of bonuses with a view to a State Government carrying on an industry. If the Government, like some doctors who believe in two kinds of quackery, tell us thai we can pay our money and take our choice, they will be degrading Parliament, As a free-trader I am absolutely opposed to the bonus system, but I would rather give bonuses to private individuals, with whom we could deal afterwards, than offer them in order to assist in the creation of a great State monopoly. Such a monopoly could not be interfered with. Either the Federal Government would have to shut out all imports by means of high protective duties, or the State Government carrying on the industry would be compelled to so reduce the price of its products as to practically tax its own people in order to prevent competition. If the iron industry were established as a State monopoly, and it were exposed to outside competition, the State would have to crawl to the Federal Parliament again and again, and ask that the duty might be increased until it reached the prohibitive point, or make its own people supply any deficiency created by the sale of the goods under cost price. One of the great principles of our constitution is that which gives the Federal Government power, with the consent of the States, to take over more and more of the States services. For instance, with the consent of the States, we have the right to take over the railways, and we might also, assume the control of their funded debts. But, in adopting the proposal to grant bonuses for the establishment of the iron industry by a State Government, we should be reversing this wholesome principle. It is proposed that £250,000 should be granted by us in order to create a new service in one of the States. There is no authority in the Constitution to justify us in granting money for the purpose, of creating a State industry over which we should have no control.
- The honorable member admits that we have the right to grant a bonus to a private individual.

- Yes ; because we could control it to some extent in that case. A private individual would carry on the industry only as long as it paid, and he would bear any loss that might be incurred, but we should have no control over the business if we once handed it over to a State Government. If the iron industry were established as a State concern in New South Wales, it might be conducted under conditions that would render it impossible to enter upon the same business in any other part of Australia; but there is no reason why we should with Commonwealth money foster an industry of that kind against the principle of equality of trade. I would point out to honorable members who hold free-trade views, that this policy of granting bonuses is associated with a scheme for the imposition of ad valorem duties. Some honorable members believe in bonuses pure and simple, but the policy of the Government is that the moment the iron industry has been established us the result of the bonus system, heavy ad valorem duties shall be imposed to keep it in existence. Therefore, I warn honorable members who profess free-trade principles, that they would not be voting for bonuses pure and simple, but for bonuses coupled with protective duties of a highly objectionable, character. I hope the committee will reverse the vote previously recorded. It was then generally understood that the States would have cheerfully acquiesced in the proposal. We are now, however, dealing with this question in the .'light of the fact that the States will have nothing to do with it at present. The Government have in this matter displayed very bad judgment. Why should we have been called upon to waste week after week in the discussion of proposals which were not embodied in the Government policy, and for which there is no urgent need? When the Prime Minister issued his manifesto, the principle he enunciated was " revenue without destruction." The Tariff' was to be framed primarily for the purposes of obtaining revenue, but its incidences were to be such that they would not harshly interfere with existing industries. Our State finances are still in such a position that no man can thoroughly understand them, and yet the Government ask us to vote £250,000 for the purpose, not of maintaining a struggling industry, but to encourage the establishment of an absolutely new enterprise. The proposal is untimely, and should, on this account alone, be rejected. What right have we, until we know how our finances will stand, to vote £250,000 away - which will involve the raising of revenue to the extent of £1, 000,000? Where is the money to come from? We might be committing ourselves to an expenditure which would seriously cripple our finances. It has been strongly urged 07.1 the one hand that we should dispense with loans, and endeavour to construct necessary public works out of the Consolidated Revenue Fund, and yet, at the same time, the Government propose to give away £25.0,000 to establish an industry which, in spite of all bonuses, may prove a rank failure. We have no right to adopt either the original or the amended proposal. Apparently we have no responsible government here. I have asked the Minister for Trade and Customs if he intends to stand or fall by the proposed amendment, but I can get no answer. Are we to be told that the Government, if defeated, will pass the Bill even in an emasculated form ? If so, Ministers will not be discharging their duties according to the first principles of political honour. Are they prepared to father in another Chamber a measure of which they do not approve 1 If they do not disapprove of it, why should they seek to recommit it 1 As I have said, I am entirely opposed to the bonus system in any form, and especially to bonuses of which certain Tariff arrangements are the complement. Further, I am strongly averse to any attempt to introduce a system of socialism which makes an enormous departure from the main principles of the Constitution. This proposal was not before the country at the last general election, and I do not believe it would be favoured by the majority of the people.

- I think the position taken by the honorable member for Wentworth is a sound one. It might be urged by some honorable members that it is useless to seek for any promise from the Government, because it would be impossible to rely upon them for any length of time. First of all they introduced a Bill which was intended to assist in the establishment of the iron industry by means of private enterprise. The committee, however, amended the Bill so as to provide that bonuses should be offered to State Governments only. This was a complete reversal of the Government policy, but Ministers led honorable members to believe that the alteration was just what they desired, and they cheerfully adopted it. Now they have changed front once more, and are asking honorable members to upset the work already done. Is not that a wonderful position for any Ministry to assume ? Should the purpose of the Government in recommitting this Bill be defeated, do they intend to resign? Do they propose to stake their official existence upon the result of their action? Anybody who knows them knows that in their vocabulary the word "Billet" is spelt very differently from the word " Bill," and consequently will not suspect them of- entertaining any such serious intention. If they are defeated upon their present proposal, we shall still find them hanging on to their billets. Perhaps we may even witness the spectacle of the Minister for Trade and Customs rising to declare that, despite what has happened, the Government are quite prepared to swallow whatever the committee choose to present to them. Many reasons were given by the acting leader of the Opposition why honorable members should vote against the amendment. Having considered the matter very carefully, I cannot see my way to abandon the position which I previously took up in this connexion. I have consistently opposed the bonus principle. I oppose its application to private individuals upon the ground that we have no light to assist any class at the expense of the rest of the community. On the other hand I claim that no State is in need of the pecuniary help which we should afford it by the passing of this Bill. The least powerful of them is quite able to struggle along without any such aid. My object in voting as I did upon a previous occasion was to insure that private individuals should not receive this artificial encouragement. The more I study the matter the more I am convinced that, owing to the very scant deposits of iron ore throughout the Commonwealth, this is an industry which should be controlled by the State. Evidently if it were placed in the hands of one or two private individuals it would be sure to develop into a monopoly. The same arguments which apply to the State ownership of railways are equally applicable to the State control of the iron industry. Honorable members should recollect that there are not more than one or two big deposits of iron throughout the Commonwealth.
- There are many more than that.

- There are not many deposits of true commercial value. After closely examining the matter from all points of view, it seems to me highly undesirable that any private monopoly should be created in connexion with the production of iron, and therefore I do not intend to reverse my previous vote. That vote was given for the express purpose of defeating this Bill. My imagination did not then depict the depths to which the Ministry are prepared to descend. I did not realize that, though the whole purport of the measure might be changed, they would still be prepared to accept it as their own. I never dreamed that Ministers would be ready to proceed with the Bill in a form absolutely different from that in which it was introduced. I should like to know how any honorable member who supports the clause as it stands can, at a later stage, turn round and say - " I voted in favour of granting a bonus to the States for the production of iron, but, because that proposal was defeated, I am now prepared to offer the same encouragement to private individuals." I shall vote for the amendment ; but, having done so, it will be impossible for me subsequently to favour granting a bonus to private individuals. The Ministry seem to be pushing this measure forward without rhyme or reason. Originally they fixed the date upon which it should come into operation as the 1st July of this year. That date has now passed, and because the Government saw that it was otherwise impossible to get the Bill through the House, they have given a reluctant assurance that if it be carried they will possibly allow a day or two to elapse before they make it operative by proclamation. The object of providing for its enforcement thus early is to prevent people in other parts of the world from knowing that any encouragement is to be offered to private enterprise to engage in the production of iron. This knowledge will thus be confined to one or two firms who happen to be acquainted with what is transpiring here. The Minister for Trade and Customs has affirmed that he is almost certain that one or two firms will embark upon the undertaking. As he has seen the prospectus which they have issued, I should be glad if he would inform honorable members of the estimated cost of production as it is set down in that document. That information has been carefully concealed from us. It has only to be pointed out to the Minister that there are one or two individuals who are prepared to engage in this enterprise, and he immediately becomes alert and eager to push any measure through this Chamber.
- I wonder if there is a second man in the committee who would make that statement 1
- A good many think it.
- I do not believe that there is one who thinks it, including the honorable and learned member himself.
-There are hundreds and thousands who believe it. Has the Minister ever shown any consideration for the thousands of people who have been ruined through the drought ?
- I must insist upon the honorable and learned member confining his remarks to the question before the Chair. He must know that he is travelling altogether beyond the standing orders.

- -I submit that for the purposes of comparison it is perfectly competent for me to show that if this Bill be carried, the bonuses payable Tinder it will be appropriated by . one or two firms only. I was pointing out that no man is consistent in declaring that he is in favour of granting a bonus for the production of iron to the States exclusively, and afterwards affirming that he is willing to grant the same encouragement to a particular individual or set of individuals. The Minister for Trade and Customs himself made one declaration upon this point on Friday last. Having affirmed that he is in favour of granting a bonus to the States, which is equivalent to collecting money from the people and handing it back to them, how can he consistently declare that his words had no reference to the people of Australia, but were limited to the. members of a particular syndicate? These are the people of whom the Minister was thinking, and so far as language goes, seeing that there are probably more than one in the syndicate, he may be perfectly right in speaking of " people." But the Minister did not say from how many people the money had to be taken, and the. passing of this Bill will make the taking of the money none the less robbery. Wherever I find robbery, legal or otherwise, I shall denounce it, because I am against all injustice and oppression. The pity is that we too often find men who are skilled in the law using their abilities, not to uplift, but to degrade the people ; and there is no doubt that the intent in the present instance is. to take from the whole of the community in order to give to individuals. I should be swerving from my duty if I did not oppose such a proposal, and I intend to fight this Bill at every step. I shall vote against the amendment proposed by the Government, and for the BUI as it now stands ; and I trust that many honorable members intend to do likewise, so that we may have the pleasure of seeing what the Government will do in the event of a defeat. None but a prophet can tell what action the Government, may take under the circumstances, because they seem to be guided by no principles of honour or reason. Past Ministries in Australia, in case of a defeat of the kind, would have resigned, but from the facing-both-ways attitude assumed by the Government we know that, whatever may happen, they will say that that was their exact intention all along. It behoves honorable members to vote steadily for the Bill as now presented, if only to keep Ministers to their professions in favour of such a measure.

- It is my misfortune, so far as concerns this Bill, to differ From several of the party with whom I act. I do not, however, differ ' from all of the free-trade party, because a considerable number are, like myself, in favour of bonuses and. against duties on iron.- I should like to give the committee the benefit of the opinion of the community of Launceston, which is, perhaps, the most free-trade in Australia. During the federal elections another free-trader and myself addressed, at the Albert Hall, Launceston, a packed audience of 2,000 or more, and, at the same time, an opposition meeting was held around the corner, the chairman of which said he considered himself fortunate in having fourteen people present. The Chamber of Commerce, Launceston, has forwarded to me the following resolution : -

quote.para: That this Chamber is clearly of opinion that any bonus granted by the Federal Parliament should be to stimulate private enterprise, and not for State monopoly. A copy to be forwarded to the Honorable C. C. Kingston and each of Tas mania's representatives in both Houses, and to solicit their support and interest to give effect to the views expressed.

talker.name: COOK, Joseph
Mr JOSEPH COOK

talk.start.para: - That is not a declaration in favour of bonuses per se.

- It is a declaration, indirectly, of a desire to see bonuses granted to private enterprises, and not to the States. I ask the labour party where is the sense in excluding from amongst us capital absolutely necessary for carrying on enterprises by means of which an enormous amount of labour will be employed ?
- We are not excluding capital, but trying to exclude the capitalist.
- We cannot do without the capitalist when we want his capital.
- We do not want his capital ; there is sufficient capital in the country.

- The labour party desire, above all, to encourage such enterprises as will furnish a large portion of the community with the means of support, and it is 3hort-sighted on their part to decry and discourage the introduction of capital which we all desire, and without which a great many industries would not have been flourishing amongst us to-day.

- This subject has been exhaustively discussed,, honorable members having, entered upon an elaboration of detail on the two former occasions when the Bill was before us,- and I shall do no more now than make a few remarks on the question- immediately before us. Owing to having to leave the House earlier .than I expected, I had no opportunity of hearing the speech of the Minister for

speech.para: Trade and Customs last week, but on looking through the remarks which the honorable gentleman then made, I confess -I cannot, place very much reliance on the Canadian statistics as published in the Year Book of Canada. The Minister made a strong point by comparing the returns of 1900 with the returns of 1901, but I do not think that one line of figures, which forms the basis of the Minister's argument, is very trustworthy. As to production the Minister will, I think, acknowledge that the statistics from 1SS4 down to 18S9 or 1900 do not indicate the success of the bonus system.

talk.start.para: - I thought the figures for 1900' very encouraging, and the later figures much more so.

- But the Minister must acknowledge that there was a tremendous declension of exports between 1885, the year in which bonuses first became operative, and 1900. A shrinkage of exports from 35,000 tons to 6,000 tons does not indicate success.
- I did not bother about the export figures.
- I wish to bother about all the figures, without which the sum total may not be complete.

- The last figures, quoted by no less an authority than the honorable member for Melbourne, show that 66,000 tons of pig-iron have been exported from Canada in the. first eight months of the present financial year.

- Surely the Minister must acknowledge that it is a very lame argument to rely on the comparison of two years in order to maintain the position -he has taken up in regard- to bonuses - to compare the years 1900 and 1901, when the figures from 1885 to 1900 show his case to be a bad one. If there be a cause in existence for twelve or thirteen; .years for the nOn-production of successful results, and the statistics show good, results in one year only, there must be some unknown factor to explain the apparent success of that one. year. If bonuses were in existence from 18S4 to- 1900, and the statistics indicate failure, then the apparent success in 1900. must be due- to some other cause or causes. And we need not go very far to find the' cause. The Minister, in his second speech on the bonus proposals a few weeks ago, stated that within the last five or six years there had been an investment of about 50,000,000 dollars in Canada in the production of pig-iron.
- I did not say that.
- The Minister said that five companies had been formed in the last five or six years with a capital of 50,000,000 dollars.
- I said that 50,000.000 dollars was put as the total investment in Canada, looking a little ahead ; and the honorable member will find that to be the case.
- I think the Minister must have taken his information second-hand from the Year Book.
- Yes, I did ; and it is shown that the investment increased from 25,000,000 dollars to 35,000,000, and then to 50,000,000 dollars.
- It is stated in the Year Book that within five or six years the total investment will approximate to 50,000,000 dollars.
- It does not say that 50,000,000 dollars will be invested at the commencement of that period ; the amount is then set down at from 25,000,000 to 35,000,000 dollars.
- The enormous increase of production has been since 1895.
- The honorable and learned member ought to read the whole paragraph in the Year Book.

- It is too much to ask me to inflict the whole quotation on the committee. The Year Book states that during the year1895large deposits of chromic iron were found in Coleraine, in the province of Quebec, the ore averaging over 50 per cent. of metal, the quality of which is said to be equal to that of the metal found in Sweden. It is since then that there has been an enormous increase in the invested capital, and the indication is that this increase has been brought about by the more profuse exhibition of nature's bounty, and not by the miserable percentage of profits represented by the bonus. The production of pig iron in Canada in 1884 was 29,000 tons, and 34,000 tons in 1900.
- The total local production in Canada is 102,000 tons.
- The Minister appeals to us to encourage local production from local ores.
- And it is local ore in Canada.

- The Minister's idea seems to be that ore taken from an adjoining State or province not in the Dominion is nevertheless Canadian. I suppose the Minister regards geographical proximity as bringing an adjoining province within the jurisdiction of the Dominion Parliament, seeing that the great bulk of the ore comes from Newfoundland.
- That is not the fact now.

- As I said before, it is very strange that the Minister should rely on the figures for one year in disproof of the statistics for about twelve years. In 1884 there were 29,000 tons, and in 1900, 34,000 tons. These figures do not indicate a success. The Minister says that in 1901 there were 99,000 tons. But evidently that increase is explained, not by the operation of the bounty, but by the enormous investment of American capital. If the Minister looks at the figures, he will also see that we cannot depend upon the 34,000 tons for the year 1900. For this reason : I find that in the table given as to the total production of iron ore in Canada in 1900 the figures are put down as 35,000 tons odd. In 1899 the total is given as 74,000 tons odd. But the value in 1899, for nearly , double the quantity, is put down at 240,000 dollars, and the value for 1900 at 583,000 dollars. Surely there must be some mistake in the figures; and, if so, the Minister's comparison between 1900 and 1901 is valueless, because it is based upon a set of figures the first of which is utterly unreliable. I cannot see that there is any way out of this difficulty except the explanation that there is a huge mistake in the figures. Un luckily, I cannot check them, because the StatisticalRegister for 1901 is not procurable. As to the general question of the granting of bonuses to assist industries, I take the stand in the beginning- and I am glad that it has been again mentioned by the acting leader of the Opposition, Sir William McMillan - that a law which can be taken advantage of only by a particular person is undoubtedly ultra vires.
-I do not think the acting leader of the Opposition said that.
- I state that first. I say also, in regard to the bonus policy of the Government, that a State itself is an individual. A State, in respect to our fiscal policy, has no relation to the Federal

speech.para: Parliament. We must frame a general law which can be taken advantage of by a State or by an individual. Surely if this Parliament frames a law under which a bonus can be given to a particular firm - or we will say to six firms, one in each of the different States - that would be ultra vires of the constitution ; because it would be granting a preference to particular persons as against others. It would not be an uniform law. Similarly, if this Parliament frames a law which can be taken advantage of only by a State - which is really an individual in regard to our policy - it must be a violation of at least the spirit of the Constitution and probably also of the letter of it. I, therefore, think that it is a mistake for those who have advocated the payment of bounties to States, to insist upon that policy. It may be a logical policy to prevent monopolies, but it is unconstitutional, and is open to the possibility of a great amount of political pressure from the States. Some State representatives will be trying to strengthen themselves relatively by comparing themselves with the Federal Parliament and federal politicians ; and it will be found in the future that some State politicians will be standing on the ground of the pressure they are likely to bring to bear upon federal members, with a view of getting this bounty system extended for the benefit of the States. That is a vicious element to introduce into our policy, in addition to its unconstitutionality. Besides, we are not compelled to aid the States in this way. If a State wants to give a bounty to a particular industry, it can ask permission from the Federal Parliament to grant that bounty.

talk.start.para: -Applyfor financial relief.

- Oh, no; if a State desires to give a bounty to an industry it can do so with the permission of the Federal Parliament. And it is a far more equitable course for a State like Tasmania - so well represented by my right honorable friend, Sir Edward Braddon - for the Legislature of such a State to grant a bonus to one of its own industries, if it wishes to do so. If the policy is a good one, we shall be glad to see it result in benefit to Tasmania ; and, if it is a bad one, the other States will not have to pay for an experiment which can benefit only Tasmania.

talker.name: SMITH, Arthur
Mr BRUCE SMITH

talk.start.para: - I had intended some weeks ago, when this measure was discussed in the House, to say something in regard to its general principles. But I was too late for the second reading debate, and then I supposed that I had missed my opportunity. This occasion gives me another chance to say a few words on the general principles affecting the measure. It appears to me, in the first place, that the question is very much complicated by the situation which has been brought about in consequence of the amendment carried at the instance of the honorable member for Bland. Because, I take it, that if the amendment now proposed by the Minister for Trade and Customs be carried, we shall then have the Bill before us in the position in which it originally stood, so that every honorable member will have the opportunity to say " yes " or " no " to the general principle of granting bonuses to private firms or companies.
- The Bill will then apply either to a State or to companies.

talker.party: FT; ANTI-SOC from 1906; LP from 1910; NAT from 1917
talker.name: SMITH, Arthur
Mr BRUCE SMITH

talk.start.para: - The right honorable gentleman has not very clearly announced his intention to the committee. I understood the acting leader of the Opposition to say that he thought the Minister might have made the position of the Government clearer. I am bound to say from what I have heard of the right honorable gentleman's statements this afternoon, that I am not aware of what course he proposes to take, supposing that his amendment is negatived. Because that would leave the Bill as it is now, and the Minister would be bound either to take it as it stands or to abandon it altogether. Which course he proposes to take the committee does not know. If we did know, it would lead to a clearer - and I might say a more honest - expression of views with regard to the question. It has been suggested to me - and I mention it to show what a complicated position the question is in - that, although, as a freetrader, I am opposed to all forms of bonuses, if I were to vote for the retention of the clause as it stands, including the amendment moved by the leader of the labour party, it would be the most effective way of killing the Bill. But that course would require me to put myself in the position of voting for a form of State socialism which . I utterly disapprove of , and although I might protect myself by stating that I was doing this for the purpose of more effectually killing the

speech.para: Bill, yet, at some future time, I should be open to have this vote brought up against me - probably without an opportunity of stating to those who so accused me of voting against my principles that I had explained my purpose to be a matter of mere party tactics. Therefore, I have made up my mind to vote against the proposal inserted in the Bill enabling the Government to pay bonuses to the States ; and I shall give my reasons for that course.

talk.start.para: - The honorable and learned member will vote for the amendment ?

talker.party: FT; ANTI-SOC from 1906; LP from 1910; NAT from 1917
talker.name: SMITH, Arthur
Mr BRUCE SMITH

talk.start.para: - I ah ill vote for the proposal of the Minister, but not because I am anxious to help bini. He knows that. He knows that my object is to negative a more objectionable proposal than the one he has put intO the Bill. Because I would infinitely rather see a bonus paid to private individuals than see one granted to a State ; for the reason that the granting of bonuses to States appears to me to open up an avenue for the worst form of political corruption, both in the working of a great enterprise of the kind proposed, and in creating a sort of channel through which unprincipled politicians could work all sorts of political pat-poses, by enlarging upon it and making it a sort of outlet for helping the employed and other classes who might assist them politically. But the question is not to be decided by figures such as have been mentioned by the honorable and learned member for South Australia, Mr. Glynn. From the free-trade point of view, it cannot matter what has been the. result of Canadian experiments. From that point of view, a bonus to private individuals is as objectionable, on principle, as bonuses to States. The only thing we have to consider here, as free-traders, is whether iron is a commodity upon which we may fairly collect revenue for the purposes of the Commonwealth and of the States - whether it should not be included in the ordinary category of commodities upon which we have to collect from £8,500,000 to £9,000,000? My direct purpose, then - -which may be pursued in an indirect way - is to try to kill the Bill altogether, because I say, in the first place, that it is distinctly opposed to free-trade principles. But I also say that it is opposed to the policy of the Government themselves, for the reason that, as the acting leader of the Opposition has pointed out, the policy laid down by the Prime Minister of the Commonwealth at Maitland was this - " We do not intend to protect industries ; we "are going to collect revenue." But we never heard a word at Maitland about the Government collecting a million of money more than was wanted for the Commonwealth and the States, in order to devote £250,000 out of that million to paying bonuses either to the States or to private individuals. Honorable members must recognise that every pound that is wanted for the purposes of this policy must be collected through the Customs, and it can be obtained only by collecting £4 in order to get the £1. Therefore, if in the future the revenue of the Commonwealth does not show a surplus as it has done in the past, an extra million must be raised from Customs in order to get the £250,000. And for what ? Not to prevent the destruction of industries, but to create entirely new industries in the Commonwealth. Has, that policy ever been foreshadowed by the Prime Minister, either at Maitland or elsewhere ? Honorable members will recollect what an amusing difficulty the right honorable gentleman at the head of the Customs deportment experienced when, during his speech upon the Tariff, he was endeavouring to prove to the House that the object of the Government was really to collect revenue, and how now and then the truth came out of him and we found him warming up to the subject of protection. But the part he was playing, whatever- he might have felt or might have desired, was this - " We are merely seeking revenue by means of tin's Tariff." There' is a complete reversal of that principle, because the Government are not merely seeking revenue, but they are deliberately taking four times the amount involved by this Bill out of revenue, and taxing, the people to the extent of another- £1,000,000, in order to obtain £250,000 to give away to assist certain individuals or certain States to embark upon a particular industry. Why one industry more than another no one knows. The State, as it appears to me, has no particular association or identification with the iron industry any more than it has with the timber industry. But we are asked, in the first place, to reverse the policy of the Government.
- What is their policy?

talker.party: FT; ANTI-SOC from 1906; LP from 1910; NAT from 1917
talker.name: SMITH, Arthur
Mr BRUCE SMITH

talk.start.para: - Their announced policy is to get revenue through the Customs, but their actual policy now appears to be to spend revenue as it is collected through the Customs, and to diminish the quantity of revenue obtained for the legitimate purposes announced by the Prime Minister. I am opposed to the State bonuses. I am opposed . to private bonuses, but, like all free-traders under present conditions in the Commonwealth, I am prepared to fine down, I will not say my free-trade principles, but my free-trade actions, in order that we may get enough revenue to carry out the work we have to do in the first ten years of the Commonwealth's history. We all know that at the end of that ten years we shall have an opportunity of fighting but this issue, without this revenue question to divert us, on the true principle of " yes " or " no " - free-trade or protection. But, in the meantime, we recognise that, although we are not called upon to sacrifice our principles, we have to adapt our actions to the exigencies of the situation. The question is, how can a free-trader most effectually get rid of both these proposals, the one to give a bonus to a State, and the other to give a bonus to individuals,, and leave the whole measure one for getting revenue 1 It must be by getting rid of the Bill altogether, because by so doing we shall avoid the necessity for collecting £1,000,000 of money through the Customs. My objection to the State bonus is this : - First of all, in my judgment, it is contrary to the spirit of the Constitution', because the Constitution actually contemplates that the States themselves shall give bonuses. Can it be said for a moment that when the Constitution! provides that a State may be empowered under certain conditions to give bonuses to industries within its own territory it was intended that the Commonwealth should give a bonus to a State? Why was it contemplated that a State might give a bonus, to an industry within its own territory? Because it was recognised that inasmuch as the State in which that industry was carried on. would benefit as against the other States by its establishment, therefore the cost of carrying it on should fall upon that particular State. Therefore the Constitution provided; that ! if any industry were to be started and [ maintained in any particular State the , money which was required to give it this ' artificial support should come out of the funds of that State. Is it not a complete contradiction of that principle to ask the Commonwealth, consisting, of six States, to put it* hands into its pockets and take from them a sum of money sufficient to artificially assist an industry in a particular State ? No one doubts for a moment that there is only one State of any importance in which this industry is likely to be established on any large scale. I am quite aware that the Tasmanian people are sanguine enough to expect that this may lead to the establishment of a very large industry in that State. I do not propose to argue against the possibilities of Tasmania, but every one knows that there is no State so well adapted to the furtherance of this industry as New South Wales. What follows ? It follows that this means that the people of New South Wales are to be assisted in the development of this industry at the expense of every other State in the Commonwealth. It is a very great pity that we have not in existence at the present time the Federal Count, which we have required for many months past, in order that a. question of this kind might be decided at a very early date in its. existence. I feel satisfied that under section 91 of the Constitution not only is the question arguable, but that there are strong probabilities that a Federal Court would prevent the diversion of Commonwealth moneys, coming, out of the revenues of the six States, to amy particular State for- the encouragement of an industry within the territory of that State. But I have other objections- to a State bonus, many of which apply to private bonuses, though to a State bonus particularly. We are all too well aware of the . effects- resulting from putting any enterprise into the hands of a State. We know that in the- history of our railways until the institution of commissioners solved, the difficulty - if it did solve the difficulty - they have been a means of enabling, politicians to put their friends by tens, hundreds, and thousands, into the public service of the country. We know that whenever anything in. the nature of a private enterprise has come into the hands of a Government, the result has been the same. In the face of that, and in the face of the experience of all the States with their railways, some honorable members are now prepared to1 indorse a proposal to put into the hands of a State an industry to which there can be no limit. Parliament has some control over a railway, but it cannot be doubted for a moment that the experience of all countries in the world is that the State cannot work an industry as cheaply as can private enterprise. If the State undertook this enterprise, politicians would be putting hundreds of people into the industry at a minimum wage irrespective of the amount of work done for that wage, and when in time it was discovered that the industry was involving the State in loss, the State would then request the Commonwealth Parliament to increase the import duty upon the commodity, in order to enable it to compete with a similar commodity coming from other parts of the world. Under this proposal we shall really be creating what will be one of the most dangerous and most troublesome institutions in the Commonwealth. Upon these grounds I certainly object to this bonus being given to any particular State. Moreover, the States have declined to take up the industry. Notwithstanding the tempting invitation which has been offered to the different States Governments by the Ministry, I think I am right in saying that not one of them has intimated any desire to take this function upon themselves. Seeing that in the Constitution the States had had reserved to them the right to give bonuses themselves, I have no doubt that they were very much astonished - if they had not carefully followed the course of events in this House - to find that it was actually proposed to give them bonuses to carry on State industries. Turning to the question of a bonus to private industry, I have another sort of criticism to offer. My criticism of bonuses to private industry is this : that even from the point of view of the protectionists, the proposal is premature. Wo must remember that it was only in January of last year that, for the first time in the history of Australia, the whole of this Commonwealth was offered as a market to this particular enterprise. We know that for years past attempts have been made in New South Wales to open up this industry. Ministries there have been approached in order that a contract might be offered for a very large supply of railway iron, and whenever the persons interested have been told by freetrade Ministers that this enterprise must stand upon its own merits, they have always replied in these terms - " We are shut out of Victoria b)' their Tariff. We are shut out of Queensland and South Australia and every other State in which railway iron is required for State railways." But in January of last year the whole situation was altered, because by the introduction of Inter-State free-trade the whole of Australia with its population of 4,000,000 became a market for the enterprise.
- I do not think that Victoria charged a duty upon railway iron.
- There was no duty on rails in Victoria.
- Surely no Government imposed such a duty !

talker.party: FT; ANTI-SOC from 1906; LP from 1910; NAT from 1917
talker.name: SMITH, Arthur
Mr BRUCE SMITH

talk.start.para: - It was said so. That was the answer given by Mr. Mitchell, who, as' many New South Wales members know, was endeavouring to start the industry in that State. His answer was that he was shut out of the other States and had only the limited market of New South Wales.
- He had not read his Tariff.

talker.party: FT; ANTI-SOC from 1906; LP from 1910; NAT from 1917
talker.name: SMITH, Arthur
Mr BRUCE SMITH

talk.start.para: - It may interest honorable members to know that, when I had the honour of filling the position of Minister of Works in New South Wales, Mr. Mitchell, representing a very large iron industry, approached the Government and made this practical proposal. He pointed out that when the Government bought their railway iron in England, they had to pay shipping charges, insurance, and the cost of cartage of the railway iron to the particular part of the State in which it was required. He made the suggestion that the Government should undertake to buy from a prospective company 150,000 tons of railway iron at a price equivalent to the English cost, with shipping, insurance, and cartage charges added. The Government considered the proposal and offered to do what was asked. Mr. Mitchell took some time to consider the matter, and he actually went to England for the purpose. The answer then came to the Government that, if they would give the company a 10 per cent, advantage, they would accept the contract and start the industry in New South Wales. It ended in nothing, but it satisfied me that there is no necessity for a bonus at all. As the Minister for Trade and Customs and the Treasurer are aware, there was a firm or syndicate in existence many months ago, dealing with the New South Wales Government, who were prepared to take a contract for the railway iron required for the New South Wales railways upon much better terms than those now proposed by giving them a bonus. Seeing that it is admitted that in New South Wales there are very large iron deposits, and an unlimited quantity of coal, and seeing that only about eighteen months have elapsed since the market of the whole of Australia was thrown open to this industry, it is certainly premature that the Commonwealth Parliament should now be asked to tax the people of the Commonwealth to the extent of £1,000,000 in order to give this artificial support to an industry which we have no reason to suppose will not come into existence by natural means in a reasonable time. On freetrade principles, therefore, I. am opposed to bonuses to private enterprise, and I am also opposed to bonuses to States. The question is - How can I, as an individual, effect my purpose best? As I have already said, it has been suggested to me as a member of the free-trade party that, by voting against the Government on this particular proposal to rescind the amendment of the labour party, the Bill would be made so objectionable, from the Government point of view, that Ministers would abandon it. If the Minister in charge of the Bill had told 'the committee that such was the case, I should have voted dead against it ; but inasmuch as it appears to me that the Minister is prepared to act either way in order that he may get his Bill for a bonus, or get some enactment within the very general order of leave which he has at the head of the measure - since it seems to me that he is willing to take either a State bonus or a private bonus, I think I shall effect my purpose best by voting with him in order to rescind the proposal for a State bonus, and retain the hope that, when the general bonus to private individuals again comes before the committee, I shall have an opportunity of negativing that, also. I shall vote with the right honorable gentleman who has moved the rescission of this amendment, not to help him. but with a view to defeating his Bill.

speech.para: Mr. HENRYWILLIS (Robertson)When this question was before honorable members some months since, in the form of Division VIa. of the Tariff, I delivered a speech in which I endeavoured to show that this particular industry required no protection whatever, and that consequently I should not think of voting in favour of a bonus. For many years past I have had opportunities for considering this question which many honorable members have not had, and I have gone into the subject pretty fully. I have already stated that I was in the confidence of the late Mr. Mitchell, who had this project in hand, and who had obtained from the New South Wales Government the promise that, if he established the iron industry in the State, they would purchase from him the whole of the State requirements in. the shape of iron rails, for a price equivalent to the ruling price abroad, plus freight and other charges incidental to importation. Mr. Mitchell, however, failed to establish the industry. He was not certain at the time that he would be able to secure from the other States a sufficient number of orders to make the enterprise profitable, but he believed that under federation - which was then in the air - he would be able to establish it, and that with Inter-State freetrade it would not only be able to standalone, but would become a very thriving undertaking. I have heard nothing from the Minister to cause me to believe that there was any tiling unsound in the arguments which I brought forward upon the last occasion ; but all the arguments advanced during the long and instructive debate which took place then have been passed over by him without notice. The right honorable gentleman, however, referred to some statistics of a rather doubtful character which appear in the Canadian Year Book for 1901. But it is stated there that the figures regarding the consumption of native ore are only approximate and subject to revision, and a significant note is added to the effect that the ore used was imported very largely from foreign countries likewise, a great deal of it being brought from Newfoundland, which, as honorable members know, is not part of the Dominion of Canada. When the Bill was originally in committee, I supported the amendment moved by the honorable member for Bland, which added to clause 3 the proviso which the Minister now wishes to rescind. I voted for that proviso in order to throw upon the Government the responsibility of giving encouragement to State socialism. It was not part of the policy of the Government, as announced at Maitland, to give encouragement to State socialism, and I naturally supposed that the addition of the proviso to the clause would cause them to drop the measure. But, true to his characteristics, the Minister of Trade and Customs has stuck to the Bill. I admire the man who will stick to his measures, but I should not admire the Minister who adhered to a measure which provided for the establishment of collectivism in connexion with the iron industry. Although a great deal might be said inf favour of the establishment of the iron industry by one of the States Governments, the people have not asked for an application of the principle of State socialism in that direction, and until there is an agitation in favour of it in all parts of Australia, I do not think we shall be justified in taking the course provided for in the Bill. My reason for voting for the proviso was that I considered that the most effective way of defeating the bonus system, a system to which I think all free-traders are opposed. We, on, this side, are now revenue tariffists as a matter of necessity ; but I hope that the time is not far distant when I shall be able to vote strictly according to my principles, in favour of free-trade as it was understood in New South Wales and exists in Great Britain. Of course, while revenue-taritfism is necessary, I am prepared to stick to my party in supporting it. But, as a free-trader, I think I shall be doing, my duty in assisting to retain in this Bill a proviso which will render it unacceptable to those for whose benefit it was introduced. All the authorities upon the bonus system whom I have been able to consult are agreed that if a bounty or bonus is paid for the establishment of an industry, and a portion of the customs receipts are applied for the purpose, the bulk of the community, rich and poor alike, contribute in proportion to their appetites. I contend that if a definite sum of money is to be given for what the Minister calls the " sufficient establishment" of this or any other industry, it should be levied by direct taxation, and the people who benefit most from the establishment of the industry, those who have a large stake in the country, should pay for that benefit in proportion to their wealth, rather than in proportion to their appetites and the size of their families. It is only by voting for the proviso in the clause that we can at the present time accomplish our object of wrecking the bonus system for which the Bill provides. If the Bill were passed, the people Of New South Wales would contribute 4s. of the 12s. per ton, or £83,000 of the £250,000, which it is proposed to pay for the production of pig-iron, puddled iron, and other raw material set out in class 1 of the schedule, while Victoria would contribute about another third, and the remaining four States of the Union the balance. If the establishment of the iron industry were likely to prove of equal value to every State in proportion to its population, something might be said for the proposal in the Bill ; but there are not more than two States, and, as pointed out by the honorable and learned member for Parkes, in all probability only one, New South Wales, in which the iron industry is likely to be established. That being so, the fact constitutes a strong argument in favour of patting aside the proposal. But the Bill does not provide only for the granting of bonuses. A bonus is to be given which, at the beginning, will equal approximately 20 per cent. of the value of the iron produced ; but at the end of five years it is to cease, and its place is to be taken by an import duty upon iron of 10 per cent., which is apparently to remain for all time. No doubt there are protectionists who might be found to support a 10 per cent. duty upon iron, but would any one support the establishment and retention of a monopoly by a duty, which, on the first revision of the Tariff, would probably be raised to 20or 30 per cent? A very plausible argument for the raising of the import duty from 10 per cent. to 20 per cent. would be the f act that the original bonus was equal to 20 per cent. upon the value of the iron produced, that the industry was still in its infamy, and that it employed thousands of men who would be thrown out of employment if more protection were not granted to it. We read of logrolling in connexion with other Parliaments, and we know how much lobbying has taken place since this Parliament met.

talk.start.para: - On both sides.

- Yes, on both sides. I am disgusted at it. But it leads me to believe that sufficient influence would be brought to bear upon honorable members to cause them to increase the import duty upon iron to 20 or even 30 per cent.
- Has the honorable member been lobbied ?

- I have been consulted over and over again. I do not think that anything has been said to me in respect to this Bill which should not have been said, but I know the object of the interviews, and I had experience of the lobbying which took place last year. The provision which the Government now -wish to rescind was deliberately agreed to by the committee, and it must be inferred from the action of the Government that they .are. of opinion that it should not be retained in the Bill, the proposal being no part of their policy. That being so, they will be justified in dropping the Bill if the amendment of the Minister is negatived. Surely the Government will not adopt the decision of the third party in this Chamber as their policy, and if the committee do not reverse the decision previously arrived at there will be no course open to them but to drop the Bill. The Minister stated that he was induced to ask the committee to reconsider their decision by the attitude assumed by the States ; but no other result could have been expected. If the proviso is allowed to remain, private enterprise is not likely to be encouraged, because it will be open to one or all of the States to embark upon the manufacture of iron at any time, and to bring their unlimited resources to bear against any private competitors. This would prevent capitalists from investing at least £500,000 in plant for the establishment of ironworks. An investment of this kind would in its turn involve the further expenditure of millions of money, and give employment to thousands of men. Some honorable members may ask why the States should refuse to avail themselves of the bonuses proposed to be offered. In the first place, there is very little likelihood of any State besides New South Wales being in a position to establish the industry, and that State would derive no material assistance from the granting of a bonus, because she would have to contribute very largely to the maintenance of the system. Moreover; the New South Wales Government is independent of the Federal Government, and as States Ministers are very jealous with regard to the' Federal Government, we can easily understand their dismissing the proposal with a shrug of the shoulders. If New South Wales desired to establish the iron industry she could do so with greater advantage by remaining independent of all aid from the Federal authorities. Under the bonus system proposed by the Government she would have to contribute one-third of the outlay involved by the system, and as it is unlikely that the impecunious States will be able to bear their share of the .expenditure, a further fairly heavy burden will probably fall upon the mother. State. Therefore New South Wales would have the advantage of only the Victorian contribution of one-third of the cost. This would be equivalent to 4s. out of the 12s. per ton proposed to be granted for the manufacture of iron. If New South Wales were to establish ironworks entirely on her own account, she would lie able to obtain, her own materials where she chose. She might, for instance, obtain supplies of hematite, which is required in the manufacture of pig iron, from New Caledonia. Upon this subject George Griffith, in his work, In anUnknownPrison Land, says : -

quote.para: At Prony, not only the rocks and the boulder?,, but the very sands of the shore themselves were of iron - sometimes pure, but as a rule containing from 85 to 90 per cent, of the metal.

Millions of tons of it ave lying round the shores of one of the finest and safest natural harbors in the world. A thousand miles away are the coal fields of New South Wales. Since it pays to ship copper and iron from Spain, and even South America, to Swansea, one would think it would pay to ship this to Newcastle: However, there it lies, waiting, I suppose, for some one to make fortunes out of it.

That is the finest deposit of ore in these southern seas, and would be extremely valuable to New South Wales. Freedom to draw upon the resources of New Caledonia would be worth more to New South Wales than 4s., or even 12s., per ton bonus.. Probably this is one of the reasons which actuated the New South Wales Government in intimating that they had no intention to avail themselves of the provisions of this measure. Sir John See, in his reply to the 'Minister for Trade and Customs, said : -

I desire to inform you that my Government have given the fullest consideration to the matter of the establishment of ironworks and works of a kindred character, and are of opinion that such should be carried out by private enterprise rather than by the Government of the State. I might add that we favour both a duty and a bonus, and should be glad to support any action taken by the Federal Government in regard thereto.
That is a very courteous reply, and such ! as one would expect from the Govern- j ment of an important State like New 1 South Wales.

talker.party: FT; ANTI-SOC from 1906; LP from 1910; NAT from 1917
talker.name: COOK, Joseph
Mr JOSEPH COOK

talk.start.para: - Sir John See was even more emphatic in his statement to Parliament. ,

- I can quite believe it. As free-traders we are fully prepared to learn that the protectionist Government of New South Wales is in favour of a protective policy in regard to the iron industry. They know that if pressure were brought' to bear upon them to establish the iron industry as a State concern, they would be at liberty to act quite independently of the reply which they have forwarded. As a free-trader I am opposed to the bonus system, and I wish it to be understood that I think that the Bill should be made unacceptable to Parliament, and that the most effective way of securing its defeat is b)' retaining the proviso. The responsibility in this matter must rest upon the Government, and they must stand or fall by their policy. I do not think that the way in which I intend to vote should be interpreted to mean that I am an advocate of State socialism. In Australia, however, there are very many State socialists. They are to be found upon both sides of this Chamber, and in the ranks of the most conservative in other parts of the world. The very conditions which prevail in Australia tend to make a man a State socialist in many directions. It is not Jong since the Honorable Sir William Harcourt was asked whether he did not favour the municipalization of certain services in England, to which he replied - " Oh, now we are all State socialists." To a certain extent I think we are all State socialists, because we not only favour the municipalization of such services as gas, water and sewerage, fuel and ferries, but we have deliberately enacted that our railways, tramways, telephones, and post-offices shall be under the direct control of the State, a form of State socialism which very few of us would be willing to abolish.
- Each case must be considered upon its merits.

- Exactly. If it were the will of the people that the production of iron should be nationalized I do not think that in bowing to it one would have to swallow much more than he has done in the direction of State Socialism. But if we give a bonus of 20 per cent, upon the production of iron to private individuals, ! the probability is that, at a later stage, an attempt will be made to increase it to 30 per cent., and. thereby increase the railway freights to farmers and other primary producers.
- Oh, no.

- The right honorable gentleman knows much better than I do what is asked of Parliament upon occasions. I can quite conceive of this Parliament being requested at some future period when the Tariff is under revision, to increase the bonus proposed to be granted under" this Bill, and I think that the advocates of such a proposal would be able to make out a plausible case by urging that the encouragement which had been afforded the industry was insufficient. But I should like to point out to honorable members that the possibilities of the iron trade in Australia are enormous. The ordinary requirements of the States themselves are considerable. For example, in connexion with the railway which it is proposed to construct between Kalgoorlie and Port Augusta, besides the steel rails required, pipes will need to be laid along the whole route - a distance of 1,000 miles. Then the consumption of iron in the construction of the transcontinental railway from Oodnadatta to Pine Creek will be enormous. I am convinced, from correspondence which I have had with iron masters in England, that capitalists are quite prepared to establish this industry in Australia without any encouragement being granted to them in the way of protection, provided they are guaranteed the trade of the several States. Knowing that, I am perfectly satisfied that ironworks can be profitably established here without 'any artificial aid. My parliamentary experience, and my observations of the working of a protective system extending over many years, convince me that if we once establish this industry by granting a bonus to private individuals, that bonus, in the form of a protective duty, will not be withdrawn from them in my lifetime, or in that of the Minister. The money that would be paid by the people would amount to millions sterling, and their annual _ contributions would pay the interest upon millions of bonded debt with which they are now "so heavily weighted. If the iron industry is native to Australia, then it can be established in our midst without any artificial aid. Not a single argument has been adduced to show that it is not native to the Commonwealth. Indeed, there is everything to prove the contrary. The facts that in this young country an enormous demand exists for iron in various forms, and that we possess every metal required in connexion with its production - such metals, for example, as wolfram - prove conclusively that the industry is native to the soil, and requires no protection whatever, though it may need some3 encouragement in the way of guaranteeing . to it the trade of the several States. If the Government would interest themselves to the extent of inducing the States to give their trade for a certain number of years to any particular firm embarking upon this enterprise upon the lines laid down by the present leader of the Opposition when Premier of New South Wales, the industry would secure all the encouragement that it requires, and the people would benefit to a great extent. Moreover, the iron industry in Australia enjoys a high measure of natural protection, inasmuch as the freight charges upon imported iron, as I learn from the expert who recently came to Australia from London, range from 17s. 6d. to 20s. per ton. Honorable members have been informed that pig-iron is brought out as ballast, and that very little freight is paid upon imported iron. I have it, however, upon the authority of the expert from London, that the freight to Western Australia is 17s. 6d. per ton, whilst to the other States it is 20s. per ton.
- Has the honorable member contrasted oversea freights with local freights 1

- I am very glad that the Minister has referred to local freights, because it seems to me that the rails and pipes required for the great trunk line which is projected from Kalgoorlie to Port Augusta might advantageously be taken to the latter place, thus saving the i cost of 200 or 300 miles of railway haulage, as compared with that which would be incurred if they were taken to Fremantle. Similarly, in connexion with the proposed line from Oodnadatta to Pine Creek, it would be wise to send the rails to Port Darwin, inasmuch as the Pine Creek railway is only 145 miles in length, whereas Oodnadatta is 688 miles from Adelaide. As New South Wales is the State in which this industry is most likely to be established, honorable members will recognise that the local freights would be a very small consideration as compared with the natural advantages which the industry would enjoy by reason of its geographical position. I would further point out that much of the iron ore used in Great Britain is imported from Spain or South America, whilst the wolfram comes from other parts. Altogether, the oversea carriage referred to by the Minister is much greater in England than it would be if we had to import our ore to a very large extent from New Caledonia.
- The idea of some people is that it should be brought from Tasmania.

- I suppose that the expense would not be greater to bring it from New Caledonia. Off the coast of Queensland there is an island which is composed largely of wolfram. That wolfram could be landed in Sydney at a much lower cost than that for which wolfram is selling in England at the present time. We have everything that is required in connexion with the iron industry, including the iron ore, wolfram, limestone, and coal, in very close proximity to water carriage, which is the cheapest form of carriage available, and therefore we enjoy natural advantages which do not exist to the same extent in England. These advantages are such that the industry can be established in Australia without any artificial aid whatever. These are some of the reasons which will induce me to confirm the vote that I gave upon a previous occasion, and to side with those who favour the retention of the provison in the Bill. I believe in freedom of commerce as far as possible, and I hope that my vote will be the means of setting aside this measure, seeing that the object of the Government in recommitting it could only have been to . induce honorable members to reconsider their previous decision. If the committee will not reverse their previous decision, we may reasonably expect the Government to cast the Bill under the table, and I shall be very glad if that course be taken.

speech.para: Mr. JOSEPHCOOK (Parramatta).I feel that I ought to say a few words explanatory of the vote I am about to give. The honorable member for Robertson has ' declared that he will adhere to his previous

I vote with the express intention of trying to kill the Bill ; find that, I believe, is the attitude of other honorable members on my own side of the Chamber. Whilst listening to the honorable member for Robertson and others, I have been wondering whether the reasons which actuate them also influence the minds of the honorable member for Melbourne Ports, the honorable member for Bourke, and other ultra-protectionists. We are told that in the opinion of some honorable members the Bill must contain a clause as proposed by the Government, in order that it may pass this and the other House ; consequently, there is a complete divergence of view amongst honorable members who are taking common action in connexion with the amendment. I voted for the amendment of the honorable member for Bland, being of opinion that if a bonus had to be given it was preferable to give it to a State rather than to an individual. But circumstances have since changed. We have had the distinct announcement by the States Governments, without exception, that they will not undertake the enterprise. Nothing could be more definite or unmistakeable than the pronouncement of Sir John See,who, in addition, has distinctly stated, in response to queries in the Parliament of New South Wales, that his Government have made up their minds to have nothing to do with the establishment of State ironworks. The proposal before us is therefore not free from difficulty to one who, like myself, does not believe in bonuses, but has an anxious desire to see the industry started. I believe the industry could and would be started even without the aid of a bonus, and if we vote to retain the clause as at present, in view of the expressed intention of the States Governments, we shall not only kill the proposal for a bonus, but also prevent the possibility of outside persons undertaking the industry; for no private company would venture on such undertakings with the menace of a State bonus over them. If the Governments will not undertake the enterprise, the least we can do is to leave the way open for private individuals. I understand that the capital is already at hand, and everything favours the undertaking by private enterprise at an early date. At any rate we have now an adequate market, and the possibility of production on a competitive scale ; and to maintain the clause at present would simply mean the shutting out of any chance of the establishment of the industry, even without any aid from the Government. I shall maintain my own principles at the later stages of the Bill, and resist any proposal to kill the enterprise while trying to kill the Bill.

division.header.para: Question - That the words proposed to be omitted stand part of the clause - put. The committee divided.

talk.start.para: - I understood the Minister to say that he was willing to make a compromise with regard to the period during which the States should have priority of claim for the bonus.
- The honorable member for Bland previously refused to accept a compromise.

- Certainly ; because I did not think it was adequate. But seeing that we cannot get all we want, I am quite prepared to now accept the compromise of giving two years' priority to the States. We ought to have some indication of the present Ministerial attitude.

- When there was some doubt as to whether the States were likely to undertake the iron industry, I was inclined, in the first instance, to fix a period during which they might have preference of claim for the bonus. Since that time, however, we have had the fullest information on the subject.
- But the Minister expressed his willingness to make such a compromise after he got the information from the States.

- I do not think so. If a promise of that sort were made, there is no doubt that an attempt ought to be made to fulfil it ; but the position has been properly and strongly put that such a provision would amount to a sort of threat that private enterprise might at any moment be exposed to competition with a subsidized State Government. I am inclined to think that the better course would be not to introduce a limitation of the kind. It would be useless and open to objection as a standing menace to private individuals embarking on the enterprise.

speech.para: Mr. CONROY(Werriwa).- It would be sufficient explanation for the Minister to say that the promise was given to the honorable member for Bland before it was known that the Government would have a majority of six in the division just taken. Now that the voice of the Committee is in favour of the Government no more need be said. Perhaps if the debate continues a little longer, the Minister may be able to think of some other reason than that I have indicated, or he may change his mind with the same readiness he showed a few minutes ago. Then again, on two occasions last week the Minister said he was in favour of giving bonuses to the States. If he is in favour of that policy, how can he favour giving bonuses to individuals? I trust that any honorable member who voted in favour of State bonuses will be careful to give his reasons before he departs from that vote and supports a proposal enabling the bonuses to be granted to private individuals. Iron is the raw material of over twenty trades. Are we to tax the twenty for the benefit of one" The proposal of the Minister is not only to tax them in this way, but, in addition, to impose a protective duty of 10 per cent. Iron is more largely used than is any other material, and the very fact of imposing this duty will tend largely to discourage manufactures. But I do not think there will be much backsliding from amongst those who are in favour of the State as opposed to private individuals undertaking the iron industry. Let honorable members look at the energy the Minister has displayed in connexion with this question. Look at the way he has spoken to his brief ! But he has not ventured to state his reason for changing his opinion on the question of the manufacture of iron by States or individuals. This is the man who originally came here with a character for standing up to his opinions. Apparently, in his view, standing up for one's opinions means only standing up for them when there is a majority in their favour. My objection to the clause as it stands is that we are asked to give a bonus to a set of individuals, and not one, word of argument has been adduced in favour of it. The Estimates are nob yet before us, and we do not even know where the money is to come from.

talk.start.para: - I do not wish to be unfair or uncharitable, but it is remarkably strange to see the Minister for Trade and Customs in the new guise of champion of private enterprise when the other night we heard him so eloquently claiming that the manufacture of iron was a proper subject for governmental control.
