He then pointed out that his only difficulty was to know whether the States Governments would take the matter in hand, and he said that if he were assured that they would, no member of this House would be more ready to give them that opportunity and to assist them in every way than he would. Now the Minister is asked whether he will give the States the reasonable period of two years within which to consider their position. Up to the present the matter has not been seriously considered by the States as States. A hurried decision has been arrived at by different Governments for the time being, but though they control the affairs of the States to-day they may be gone to-morrow. Because of that opinion the Minister ranges himself under the banner of private enterprise, and is fighting, not for what he professed last week, but for a set of private capitalists. The suggestion thrown out by the honorable member for Bland is not an unreasonable one, and certainly it did not meet with the Minister's opposition last week - that is, that the different States should have an opportunity of making up their minds. Why should not a proviso be inserted in the clause to the effect that it should be open to the States to avail themselves of this provision for the next two years, after which it shall be open to private enterprise?
- I have been looking up the remarks I made on a previous occasion, and which have been referred to, and I have found them.
- The remark was made by way of interjection, I think.
- I wish to give honorable members the full benefit of whatever I said, not abating one jot or tittle.
-The right honorable gentleman should know whether the principle isa good one or not, without reference to what he said last week.
- As regards the suggestion made, what I am afraid of is that the States will not take up the matter of the manufacture of iron, and the thing will be " stuck up."
- Give the people an opportunity of saying whether the States Governments should take it up.
- This is what I find I said, amongst other things : -

speech.para: I do not flinch from the position I previously took up. If the States are willing to undertake this work, let us give them a reasonable period in which to do so. But do not let us conserve to them the right for all time, and give the private individual no chance.

talk.start.para: - That was after the Minister had received the answers to his inquiries.

- Yes, it was and I am reading the passage in order to make it available to honorable members at the earliest opportunity. Of course, when I was put to it, what I said was this -"I do not think there is a chance." I do not think there is the slightest chance of the States undertaking this work.
- Give them three months.

- No. I will not. Honorable members know that it is not our intention that this industry should be jumped at a moment's notice by anybody. It is our intention that it should be open to fair competition by a good many. We do not desire to create it for any particular individual, company, or State. On that point our idea would be in connexion with the schedule to insert a provision that the bonus should not be payable except as regards a future time, both as to commencement and expiration. Honorable members know that this question was raised in connexion with the date of the commencement of the Act, and the Government then promised-
- But that was not what the Minister was referring to.
- No the question has been discussed from two points of view.

talker.party: FT; ANTI-SOC from 1906; LP from 1910; NAT from 1917
talker.name: COOK, Joseph
Mr JOSEPH COOK

talk.start.para: - The right honorable gentleman practically indorsed the proposal of the honorable and learned member for Northern Melbourne.
- It was my proposal originally.

- The proposal of the honorable and learned member f or Northern Melbourne covered two points - one having reference to the right of purchase and the other having reference to wages, but, so far as I recollect, the honorable and learned member did not speak upon this point at all.
- Yes, he did.

- He was not the one who suggested it by any manner of means. He directed his attention to the question of the right of purchase and to the question of wages. I think that under all the circumstances honorable members have a right to expect us to fix a future date for the commencement of the bonus. That would give all an opportunity of getting word of the competition. I am sorry that in view of the improbability of the States taking up the industry, there should be any special condition of the kind, but I think it is possible to establish a claim for a reasonable time during which preference shall be accorded to the States over a private individual. The Government, therefore, will not resist a reasonable proposition in the direction.

speech.para: Amendment (by Mr. McDonald) proposed -

quote.para: That the following words be added, "Provided that for two years after the commencement of this Act any State Government shall have prior claim to such bonus."

talk.start.para: - I do not thirds the words used by the honorable member will carry out the idea effectually. I shall draft a proviso, if honorable members will agree to that course, which will have the same effect. Honorable members will recollect that I brought forward a clause with the same purpose. What I suggest is a proviso to the effect that if within a certain time any State declares its intention in a certain way - and I think it ought to be by resolution of both its Houses of Parliament - to avail itself of the provisions of this Bill, then its provisions shall apply only to the States.
- Will the right honorable gentleman make that time two years ?

speech.para: Mr.G lynn. - That will suspend the operation of the Bill for two years.

talk.start.para: - Is the right honorable gentleman going to agree to that?
- I am going to submit a proviso which will give to the States a preference for a limited time. We proposed that before.
- It was not accepted before.
- No, it was not accepted.
- Then why does the right honorable gentleman go back upon his party now ?
-For this reason : That certain expressions were used in debate which probably give honorable members the right to say that they expected it ; and, therefore, we intend to propose it.
-paterson. - Will the preference be given for three or six months ?
- Surely the right honorable gentlemen is not going to propose two years ?
- We shall not have a general election before that time.
-Then we shall set aside the Bill until after the general election.
- The right honorable gentleman will do himself a lot of harm if he does this.
- I am inclined to think that two years is, under the circumstances, too long.

talker.party: FT; ANTI-SOC from 1906; LP from 1910; NAT from 1917
talker.name: COOK, Joseph
Mr JOSEPH COOK

talk.start.para: - Passing a Bill to operate in two years' time is ridiculous.

- I say that perhaps a proviso of the description to which I refer should extend for a period of one year, which should be long enough for the States to make up their minds on the subject. I believe that they have made up their minds, and are not likely to depart from the decision at which they have arrived. We have certain information on that point ; but, as I have said, for the purpose of keeping faith with honorable members in the strictest sense of the word, I am prepared to submit a proposal to give preference to the States for one year.

speech.para: Sir WILLIAMMcMILLAN (Wentworth). - This has been a remarkable exhibition of inconsistency. The right honorable gentleman only two minutes ago indorsed expressions used by one or two honorable members to the effect that if there were any attempt to tamper with this proposal by tying it up, it would be impossible, under the shadow of the threat of a State taking up the industry, for any private individual to act. The right honorable gentleman agreed with that. He admitted that the argument was perfectly sound, and he said that they had approached the different States Governments, and that each had refused to take action. He also said that he was perfectly certain that the States would refuse to touch it.

talk.start.para: - That is the reason the clause was recommitted.

- The right honorable gentleman expressed the opinion, as a responsible Minister, and on the basis of the correspondence with the States Governments, that he was perfectly certain they would not touch it for several year's. Now he turns absolutely right about face and declares that in spite of his own expression of opinion, he is prepared to agree to a' certain proposal. I say it is trifling with the whole thing. It simply shows that it would have been far better, far more constitutional, and far more in accordance with the honour of responsible government, if, when this Bill was wrecked before, the Government had thrown it under the table. It is a very serious position that this Chamber is placed in. We are face to face with the question whether there is any responsibility in what we call Ministers of the Crown. If this kind of thing is to proceed further it will be far better to vote for a committee to manage the business of this House. The right honorable the Minister for Trade and Customs, who has some reputation for strength of mind and strength of character, should surely know his own mind within ten minutes ? We have belittled ourselves not only before the people of Australia, but before the people of the Empire. I shall explain that. We passed a resolution here the other day, and the Government gave its countenance to a proposal by which private individuals would have an opportunity of starting an industry of this kind. That course was taken on the good faith of the Government in the passing of a certain part of our Tariff, and yet the very Government who proposed this have turned round and accepted an absolutely different principle, and have thrown over those people who attached some importance to the faith of Ministers. What are we to expect from responsible government if no one can know what the intentions of Ministers are ? The best thing we can do now is to negative the whole clause, and let the Bill be at once destroyed. That is the only proper course to pursue. I do think that my honorable friends of the labour party ought really to accept the opinion of this House upon the matter as so far expressed.
- " So far " is good.

- If we suspend this proposal for a year, or for two years, we shall practically be attempting to legislate for the next Parliament. If a year is proposed we shall be then under the shadow of a general election. What private enterprise in the world would attempt to undertake an industry of this kind under those circumstances? I say we are trifling with the whole thing from beginning to end. Let us decide upon one thing or the other, like responsible people, and not make ourselves the laughing stock of the outside public, as we are doing. I hope no attempt will be made to interfere with the vote which has been taken. I intend to vote against the clause altogether, in order to save time and have the Bill put under the table.

speech.para: Mr. WATSON(Bland).- It is well enough for the honorable member for Wentworth to talk of accepting the vote of the committee ; but those of us who desire to go a little but of the beaten track in political movements find it rather an unwise thing to accept the vote of the committee, because we do not quite know how soon that vote may be changed. So far as the opinions of some honorable members are concerned, they have changed very considerably within the last few weeks, and the Minister has changed his opinion within the last few minutes. I understood that he was going to stand by the proposal he made last week.

talk.start.para: -Sodid we who voted with him.

- If the honorable member for Melbourne had been in his place, and had heard the proposal the right honorable gentleman made last week, he would understand that it was that the States should have priority of claim to the bonus for a period of two years.
- I never understood that.

- The Minister now puts forward another proposal which, from the point of view of those who desire to see the States given an opportunity of going into this industry, is not worth a snap of the finger. What opportunity is afforded to a minority that may exist at present in a State to become a majority in favour of entering upon this enterprise in twelve months' time? There would not be time even to shift a Ministry, clinging limpet-like to their seats, in that period. We cannot expect the people of New South Wales, of Tasmania, or of any other State in which coal and iron are found together, to give an expression of opinion upon this subject, except at a general election, and no general election is due in any of the States likely to enter upon this industry for the next two years. Unless we allow a few years during which we may get an expression of opinion from them, it is utterly useless to put forward any such proposal as the Minister now indicates that he is willing to agree to. So far as I am concerned, therefore, I say that I have no option left but to vote against the Bill and the clause. I say, at the same time, that I am prepared to vote for such a proposal if sufficient time is. given. I think the honorable member for Kennedy ought to persist with his amendment seeking to enact a period of two years within which priority shall be given to the States. Any less period than that is of no value. Two years is even too short, but I am satisfied that we cannot expect any definite expression of opinion on this subject to be obtained from New South Wales in less than that time. The present State Ministry is not likely to take the matter up until the pressure of public opinion is strong enough to induce them to do so. I am convinced that there is every probability of that expression of opinion being given at or before the next general election, but sooner than that one cannot rely upon it. I think, therefore, that the suggestion put forward most recently by the Minister is quite different in spirit from that put forward last week, when the right honorable gentleman spoke a second time upon this subject. The Minister proposes now to give twelve months' priority to the States. The minimum period spoken of last week was two years ; the period of one year is inadequate.

- I am somewhat surprised at this reversal of attitude on the part of the Government. It is difficult for honorable members to understand where they really are. With regard to the proposal to give the States priority for a period of two years, I would point out that those who support it say in the same breath that there is not the slightest chance of the States taking advantage of it.
- I said quite the contrary.
- The honorable member said there is no chance of a general election taking place in either New South Wales or Tasmania for two years to come.
- I said that a general election would take place within two years.

- We have been informed by the Governments of those States that they have no intention whatever of taking action towards the establishment of. the iron industry as a State monopoly. Is there any likelihood that their-attitude will be changed until . there has been a general election ?
- They may be converted within less than two years. It has taken a shorter period than that to convert other Governments in regard to other reforms.

- But their hands cannot be forced until there has been an election. The sooner we have a decided opinion from the Government in regard to this matter the better it will be for all parties. On a previous occasion, when a provision similar to that now submitted by the honorable member for Kennedy was before the committee, those who now advocate it refused to accept it as a compromise ; they would have nothing less than the complete control of the iron industry by the States Governments. I am amongst those who have no fear that the persons employed in this industry would be injured if it were undertaken by private enterprise, since Parliament can always control the conditions under which it must be carried out ; but why do the Government blow hot and cold upon this matter ? I voted for the excision of the proviso because I believed that the Government would abide by the decision of the committee, but we had hardly arrived at a decision before they went back upon their own statements. Their action has been unfair to their supporters and to the committee generally.
- The Minister for Trade and Customs stated last week that he was in favour of this proposal.
- -Certainly not.
- Yes, on Friday.

- I clearly understood, that the Government would stand by the clause as it was originally introduced. We have been informed by the Minister that the States Governments refused point plank to take steps for the establishment of the'iron industry. We know that many honorable members voted for the provision, not because they are in favour of it, but because they wished to defeat the Bill, and if the Government are not now going to stand by the clause as it was originally introduced, I shall refuse to countenance the continuance of the present farcical proceedings, and, although I have told my constituents that I am in favour of granting bonuses for the establishment of the iron industry, shall vote against the Bill.

- The honorable member for Moira has rightly described these proceedings as farcical. I never knew a Minister to trifle with a committee as the Minister for Trade and Customs has trifled with this committee. If he had had any intention of supporting a proposal for the giving of fi preference to the States Governments for any period, he would not have asked the committee to- excise the proviso added to the clause on the motion of the honorable member for Bland, but would have moved the addition to it of words which would carry out his intention. The Minister could have saved all the discussion which we have had during the last three days by taking some such course as that.
- He has been in favour of our amendment right through.
- Then why did he get the committee to rescind it %
- Because he has also been opposed to it right through.

- He appears to be alternately in favour of it and opposed to it. Usually a person allows a decent interval to elapse between his advocacy of one set of opinions and his adoption of another set. But the Minister shifts from one attitude to another with the rapidity of a lightning change artist. He opposed the restriction of bonuses to State undertakings as against the interests of the industry and of the Commonwealth, and because there is no hope of any State Government establishing ironworks ; but, having got together a majority, and rescinded the proviso of the honorable member for Bland, he turns round and proposes the very thing he previously opposed. Every member in the committee has reason to complain of this change of attitude. No section of the committee can form any definite plan when the Minister departs in this way from a policy which he says he will stand by.
- It is a little extraordinary to hear the complaints of honorable members, some of whom have been away, and therefore do not know what has taken place.
- I have not been away.

- The honorable member was conspicuous by his absence from the division which took place on the 19th June. The Government have been perfectly consistent throughout in this matter, and I shall prove it to a nicety. What we are defending to-day is the attitude we took up on the memorable 19th June. There was then a great difference of opinion as to how the States would act, and we supported the proposal that a certain period of time should be given to them in which to make up their minds.
- Then why did not the Government put a provision to that effect in the Bill?
- Because a number of honorable members opposite voted against it. Some of them, the honorable member himself included, voted in a different way to-day from that in which they voted then.
- I did not do so.

- The honorable member, at my instance, paired with the honorable member for Tasmania, Sir Philip Fysh, on the 19th June. I explained to him that my colleague was absent, and asked him to pair with him. My colleague was against the establishment of a State monopoly, and the honorable member in pairing with him must be regarded as voting in favour of such a course.

speech.para: SirW illiam McMillan. -I did not pair upon that matter, but upon a different question altogether. I cannot exactly recollect what the occasion was, but when I paired with Sir Philip Fysh.it was in reference to the vote given prior to that mentioned. I did not vote in the division to which the Minister has referred.

talk.start.para: - I understood that the honorable member paired on this question. I did not obtain another pair for Sir Philip Fysh.
- That pair is not recorded in the division on my amendment.
- No. I was asked to pair, but I refused, and I did not vote upon that question.

- At any rate, whatever the position was, a number of honorable members voted for the State monopoly which they had loudly denounced, and the result was that the amendment which was proposed by the honorable member for Bland was carried by a considerable majority. Now where are we?
- Where are those honorable members, from the Government side, who voted for the amendment of the honorable member for Bland?

- Iam,not complaining of their being on my side of the Chamber tonight; but I. complain of their having been on the other side, against the Government, upon the occasion to which I have referred. They knew, however, that they had done wrong, and they have brought forth meat for repentance by voting in favour of striking out words which they assisted to insert. We are fighting for two things. First of all, we propose to place a. time limit upon the preference which is to be given to the States. When speaking upon the amendment moved by the honorable member for Melbourne Ports upon the amendment proposed by the honorable member forBland,on 19th June, I said -

quote.para: I am willing to accept the amendment of the honorable member for Bland, if he will alter it so as to read, " provided that if any State shall by act passed before the30th June,1904, provide for the establishment of "State ironworks."

talk.start.para: - I paired against that amendment with Sir Philip Fysh, and not upon the main amendment of the honorable member for Bland.

- The honorable member voted against that, as he says, and we were beaten by a majority of four, the numbers being 20 against 16. Then the division took place upon the amendment proposed by the honorable member for Bland, and it was carried against the Government by 25 votes to 12, or a majority of 13. How does our position to-night differ in the slightest degree from that we occupied on the 19th June?
- The Government have reconsidered the question, and have decided to take a different course.

- Is not our attitude precisely the same as it was ? There is no doubt about it. We were opposed to the absolute limitation of the bonuses for all time to the States, but we were in favour of a preference being, given to the States for a limited time. Upon both these issues we were beaten, and we had time for further consideration. What did we do when we- were defeated ? We reported progress immediately after the amendment was carried against us. Since then we have obtained further information on the subject, and our first object was to remove the amendment proposed by the honorable member for Bland, and carried against us.
- There is no need to remove it if a preference is to be given to the States for. a, period of two years.

- The two points were raised in different ways, and we are similarly raising them now. AVe have succeeded in removing the proviso inserted at the instance of the honorable member for Bland, and we now- find ourselves face to face with a proposal, for which we ourselves voted on the 19th June, giving a preference to the States for a limited time. I admit that there are now stronger reasons for rejecting, that amendment than existed some time ago. I have mentioned these, and 1 have pointed, out the further evidence we have with regard to the unfavorable attitude of the States.
- The right honorable member said it was- fatal.
- I do not think that I went so far. as that, although X spoke strongly. On .Friday last I said -

quote.para: If 'the States are willing to undertake this work, let us give them a reasonable period in which to do so, but do not let us conserve to them the light for all time, and give the private individual no chance.

speech.para: That statement was made in the early part of my speech.

talk.start.para: - That was after the Minister had said that the States would not entertain the idea. What is the use of giving them an opportunity of doing something which they say they will not do 1

- We cannot tell what may be done in the future. There may be a change in the attitude of the States at any time, and, in view of the wide division of opinion upon this subject, it is only fair that we should endeavour to meet the views of those who believe that there is a likelihood of the States embarking upon the enterprise. I should not be treating the committee fairly if I refused to give an opportunity of the character referred to. I have previously indicated that it is not our intention to bring the bonuses into force immediately, because it is inexpedient that we should play directly into the hands of any particular individuals. We have not departed from the lines previously laid down, and we are found to-day contending foi" practically the same principles that we fought for six weeks ago.
- But did not attempt to embody in' the Bill.
- That is hardly worthy of the honorable member.
- It is true.

- Under all the circumstances, I. resent the suggestion that there has been any change of front on the part of the Government, and I was sorry to hear the observations made by the honorable member for Moira. He was one of those honorable members who endeavoured to assist us in doing that which we are now proposing to do, namely, to give the States, by way of preference foi" a certain period, a chance to earn the bonus. The honorable member did not hold then, because the proposal was negatived when he voted for it - and that was only six weeks ago - that it was his duty to support the exclusive application of the bonus to private individuals.
- I stated my reasons then, and I stated them again to-day.

- The honorable member has shown by his vote to-day, for which we thank him, that the attitude we have adopted in resisting the limitation of the bonuses to the States, to the total exclusion of all private enterprise, is the right one. I ask the committee to give fair consideration to this matter, and to recognise that the attitude of the Government has been consistent and just throughout.

- The Minister has quoted from Hansard, but it will be apparent to honorable members when . they have the report of the Minister's speech in their hands that on the occasion to which he has referred he was- speaking, not of his intention, but of his belief. He said that he " believed " that the States should conduct such enterprises as that proposed in connexion with the establishment of ironworks, and he suggested that we should give the States a chance to do so. That is what he had always said, but in his hand at that particular moment he held a sheaf of telegrams, which he read later, and from which it appeared that the States had not the slightest intention to take advantage of the provisions of the Bill. Therefore1 what the right honorable member then said with regard to his intention had reference to his past intention. His intention when he spoke was that the whole matter should be left to private enterprise. The right honorable gentleman has referred to his utterances on Friday afternoon, but when honorable members have an opportunity to read the Ilansard report they will see that there is not one line of the context that will convey the impression, that the Minister was then in favour of giving the States one or two years in which to make up their minds. When we pleaded for time, he pointed to the telegrams as conveying the final decree of the States, and he said in so many words that the States had no intention of going on with the enterprise. In the face of that does the Minister mean to tell the committee that on Friday afternoon he was in favour of giving the States an opportunity of reconsidering the matter'! I am sure that when the pages of Ilansard come into the hands of honorable* members they will see how utterly baseless such a contention is. The Minister represented that the States had left him in such a position that he had no option but to declare in favour of granting bonuses for the encouragement of private enterprise. Now he has the hardihood to tell us that he has not changed his mind. What was he fighting for ? Why was he so anxious to recommit the Bill? There was no necessity to recommit the Bill if he had held his present view all through the piece.. I utterly deny that the Minister has treated the committee fairly. I have seen a number of extraordinary gyrations on the part of Ministers, but I am sure that no honorable member has ever witnessed or read of anything equal to the last performance of: the Minister for Trade and Customs. The honorable member for Wentworth has referred to the Government as a committee to record the votes of honorable members, but we do not want even a committee. All we require is a sort of automatic push or pull machine into which we can place our motions and then count our votes. There would be, at least, some stability in such a machine.
- What does the honorable member want ?

- We are satisfied with what the Government is now proposing, but what guarantee have we that they will not proceed upon another tack by this time to-morrow? Our position is not to be altered by charging some honorable members on this side of the House with inconsistency. Some honorable members who supported the Government to-day did so for the same reason that actuated them in voting against them on a previous occasion. They wished to kill the Bill, and they were perfectly consistent, and were perfectly within their rights in voting as they did. We do not want the Bill, which has been introduced by the Government for its own purposes. The Government have posed as the guardians and saviours of the people, and have professed to bc anxious to provide work for the unemployed, and to give private enterprise a chance, but when private enterprise had a chance the Government basely threw it over. I am sure that if any member of the syndicate interested in this matter could be permitted to express his opinion regarding the attitude of the Minister, he would use terms a hundred times more harsh than any employed by us. He says that the attitude of the Government to-day is the same as it was upon the 19th June last. That is utterly untrue.
- The honorable member must withdraw that statement.

- Very well, sir. I withdraw it, and say. that the statement of the right honorable gentleman is not borne out by the facts which I shall place before the committee. Upon the 19th June, the Ministry had not communicated with the Governments of the various States in reference to this matter, and consequently were not in possession of their determinations as they are to-day. Upon that date they did not know whether or not the States intended to embark upon this enterprise, and therefore it was perfectly consistent for them to say they were in favour of allowing the States Governments a certain period during which they should enjoy exclusive rights to the payment of the bonus. But to-day the Ministry know that the States Governments are not ready to nationalize the production of iron. Yet they now urge that we should give to the States which they say have no intention of embarking upon the enterprise a chance to do so. If that is not inconsistent with their attitude upon the 19th June, I do not know what is. Doubtless some honorable members will see their way out of this maze. If they do so it will be more creditable to their ingenuity than to anything else. I shall listen to further explanations from those who support the right honorable gentleman with a certain amount of interest, but not with amusement, because the matter is altogether too serious a one for mirth. As one who believes that the State should control this industry, I have no complaint against the Government for changing their minds in that direction ; but what guarantee have we that they will not again change their minds in the opposite direction? The Minister has said that his attitude to-day is precisely what it was on a former occasion when he was defeated by thirteen votes. The amendment of the honorable member for Bland was rescinded by a majority of six votes. Surely, with such a majority behind him, the Minister can muster enough courage to proceed with the Bill in the form which the committee previously determined it should take. I do not thank heaven for many things; but at least I thank it that I am not a Government supporter, because I can well understand the feelings of disgust, indignation, and subdued fury which must animate honorable members opposite, although it is extremely difficult, when looking at their amiable countenances, to believe that they could be furious at anything. I can, however, understand that they would be furiously indignant at such an extraordinary volte face. Take the honorable member for Melbourne Ports, as an example. On Friday he went away primed with an excellent idea which he had obtained fresh from the Minister. Probably he saw certain persons upon Sunday or Monday, and told them the position that he occupied in relation to this Bill. Now, however, he finds that he does not occupy that position. The action of the Minister does not give him a chance. If I were a Ministerial supporter I should be very loth to follow the crack of the whip. As, however, I am not a Government supporter, I can only say that we can place no reliance upon the promises of a Government, which, as we have seen times out of number, has no policy but that of the greater number of this House - no intention but that which is gathered from their whip, and no idea of statesmanship other than what is seen in the columns of the morning newspapers.
- The honorable member is travelling outside the standing orders.

- If what I have said is offensive, I withdraw it. Lacking as they do all necessary qualities of statesmen, the Ministry still essay to lead the first Federal Parliament, where politics were to be lifted up to the heavens, and where superior beings were to wander in polished halls of marble to make laws for a glorious Commonwealth. Between the promise and reality, I am sure that even the most optimistic of men must admit there is a great gulf. I entirely agree with the honorable member for Moira, who has submitted to a great deal from this Government, but has made up his mind to submit to no more.

speech.para: Sir EDWARDBRADDON (Tasmania) - I confess I am immensely surprised that the Minister for Trade and Customs, whom I have always regarded as one possessed of considerable backbone and courage, should have shown himself a mere jelly-fish - a sort of protoplasmic Minister, who is ready to yield at any moment, and upon any point I have supported this Bill earnestly, although with some degree of reluctance. That reluctance has arisen from the fact that with the passage of this measure we also carry the imposition of certain duties upon iron. However, I have supported it, and now that the States are to be allowed a certain period within which they may determine whether or not they will embark upon the production of iron, I can only say that the Bill is of no earthly use to capitalists, and that it cannot effect the purposes for which it was introduced. As I have already announced that Lam opposed to State enterprise in this direction, I shall have the dismal pleasure of voting against the Bill.

talk.start.para: - I feel that by the action of the Minister I have been placed in a position of considerable difficulty. I certainly did not understand, nor do I think now, that by the use of the words which he has read he intended to indicate his determinations to consent to defer the period when private enterprise should be able to embark upon the iron industry, and participate in the proposed bonus. I feel that if we are going to allow the States twelve months in which to decide this question, the Bill will be rendered valueless. My reading of the position of the Minister is that he came down to this House with various telegrams from the States Premiers to show that they had no intention whatever of embarking upon the enterprise, and that he- therefore wished to recommit the Bill. If there had been any desire upon his part to give the States twelve months in which to decide whether or not they would nationalize the production of iron, why did he not inform those whom he wished to support the Bill of that desire ? Personally, I am in this difficulty - I shall either have to support the proposal to give the States priority of claim for twelve months, or else vote for the rejection of the measure. I have no desire to adopt the latter course, and yetI feel it is equally wrong that we should be asked to postpone for twelve months the period when private individuals shall be allowed to embark upon the iron industry. Had the intention of the Minister been made clear, I should have known how to act. As a Government supporter, I feel that I. have been misled in this matter.

- I am sorry that. I cannot accept the proposal of the Minister for Trade and Customs. Upon a previous occasion he told us that he thought two years was a reasonable time within which to allow the States to decide whether or not they would nationalize the iron industry. If his remarks then were true, they are equally true to-day. I must certainly express my sympathy with the right honorable gentleman in the awkward position in which he finds himself. He is apparently prepared to sacrifice any principle in the Bill if, by so doing, he can catch votes. That is the position which he has adopted all through the consideration of this measure. He has got himself into an awkward position by suggesting, as a compromise, that my amendment should be limited to twelve months in lieu of two years, with the result that a number of supporters have told him that they are practically disgusted with the action of the Government in this matter. That is not a very enviable position for him to occupy. I think that twelve months is altogether too short a period within which to insist that the States must decide this question. No one can seriously regard the telegrams received from the Premiers of the different States as their final decision in this connexion. I do not suppose that the question of whether the industry should be nationalized was even discussed in Cabinet before those replies were sent. I would further remind the right honorable gentleman that it is quite possible for a change of Government to take place in the States at any time, and for the incoming. Ministers to hold quite a different set of opinions from those entertained by their predecessors. Under such circumstances, he did not treat the committee fairly in accepting the communications received from the various States Governments as absolutely final, and in endeavouring to reverse the decision arrived at by the committee the other night. It is very humiliating for the committee to vote in a certain direction to-day, and in an. opposite direction tomorrow. Such a practice is becoming common in this Chamber. If the Minister is agreeable to allow the States twelve months to decide whether or not they will embark upon the iron industry, where is the necessity to proceed with this Bill at the present time? He could drop the measure and revive it next session.
-Then why did the honorable member propose two years?
- Because the Government do not feel inclined to drop the Bill.
- Does the honorable member desire to kill the measure?

- As far as I am personally concerned I intend to vote against it. The Minister for Trade and Customs has taunted honorable members upon this side of the Chamber with having supported the amendment of the honorable member for Bland for the purpose of killing the Bill ; but I should like to remind him that a large number voted with him upon the last division from similar motives. If the honorable gentleman believes that the State should do the work, where were his principles when he told those who voted for the amendment in order to kill the Bill that he was prepared to carry the measure through without further amendment? His principles were thrown to the winds, merely because he received messages from the Premiers of the various States. The Minister is in a very peculiar position, and he will find that he has wasted a considerable amount of valuable time. He ought to know that there is no possible hope of this Bill becoming law. He has shown that he is prepared to abandon his principles and hand this bonus to a syndicate ; and I shall cast my vote against theBill.

speech.para: Sir WILLIAMMcMILLAN (Wentworth). - I do not want to prolong the debate, but I should like to say that the whole of the speeches clearly show the absolute want of determinative opinion on all sides of the Chamber. There is an absolute chaos of opinion, and neither any State nor any individual will be justified in attempting to start this industry until a further period has elapsed in which the real opinion of the country may be made known. Although perhaps a little humiliating, it would be far better for the Government, as a matter of common sense, to withdraw the Bill. Public opinion may be matured between this and next session, or between now and the election of the next Parliament; but the discussion has been of such a character, and there is such uncertainty as to a possible reversal of opinion in this Chamber, that to my mind it would be impossible for a large capitalist, or even a State, to undertake ironworks until assured by the results of another election that their position was sound and stable.

talk.start.para: - A proposal has been made that the period during which the State shall have preference shall be two years, and I have offered to make it one year. In that action I think I have, to some extent, gone further out of my way than, perhaps, I should have done on calm deliberation ; but I do so for the purpose of giving full effect to any words which. I uttered last Friday - that is the position, and I cannot get away from it. It was not in my mind that an amendment of this sort would be moved, but when my attention is called to what I said, I hold to any promise which may have been made ; no member of the Government would be " worth his salt " who did not do so. Let the position be clear - the Government have offered every concession, and can. go no further. If honorable members will not accept the proposal for a period of one year, we shall vote against a. period of two years.

- I am reluctant to advise, but I feel that we are running great risk of losing a very valuable. Bill. I feel extremely perplexed in this matter. There is a. diversity of opinion and a diversity of voting, and. whichever way we decide must have momentous consequences to this continent. I fear very much that in the conflict of opinion amongst its friends the Bill may be lost. I certainly should prefer to see the Bill in; such a form that the State and private individuals alike had the same opportunity.

speech.para: Mr.Poynton. - Does the honorable and learned member for one moment think that private enterprise would take up the industry under such circumstances?

talk.start.para: - It is only in the interests of the Commonwealth that we are attempting legislation, and if the State and private enterprise were placed on the same footing, the Commonwealth would at the earliest possible moment create the greatest amount of benefit. Until the honorable member for Kennedy spoke I was inclined, rather than risk the loss of the Bill, to vote even for his amendment, because I understood that some honorable members on the other side had declared their intention of voting against the Bill if the period were not made two years. But when the honorable member for Kennedy says that he is not a friend of the Bill, and is desirous of preventing its becoming law-
- I want a State monopoly.

- As I understand, the amendment of the honorable member for Kennedy is not proposed in any friendly spirit, and I feel that I should not be advancing the cause I wish to serve by supporting it. We all know how extremely important iron and coal are to any country which makes any pretence to becoming an industrial nation. In the current number of; the Windsor Magazine there appears a most important article, which is written by one who is undoubtedly a protectionist - Mr. Ernest E. Williams - but which contains facts and information of vital interest to us all. The writer reminds us that not merely as the possessors of a little territory which we know as the British Isles, but as an Empire, we have a tremendous future before, us, and points out that our hope lies in the development of its mineral resources. If honorable members read that article they will hesitate very much before casting a vote which may lead to the destruction of the Bill before us. Mr. Williams shows that iron, as the material for our machinery, is almost the best measure of our wealth and power, and points out that in 1870 England produced 6,000,000 tons of iron, as against 4,500,000 tons produced by the United States, Germany, and France combined. But in 1901 England and Germany each produced 7,750,000 tons, while the United States produced 15,878,000 tons. We all recollect that Mr. Gladstone ridiculed the idea that the United States, under her Tariff laws, could establish effective means of competing with England in the iron industry. Here, however, is proof of the wisdom of the Tariff provisions of the United States. I should like to read a few words from the article, because it refers directly to these Australian States. This question does not concern Victoria to any great extent as an iron producer. Victoria can hope to benefit from the industry only as a member of the Commonwealth, and, though I take no credit for the circumstance, the votes of the Victorian representatives will be the most unselfish that can possibly be given in any Assembly.
- That is something new for Victoria.
- It may be something new for the honorable member for Barrier to recognise the fact. The article, which is entitled "Our Hope of Industrial Dominion," says-

quote.para: As it is impossible to sketch within my limits the . most cursory outlines of the Empire's slumbering wealth, I will speak of these two test products to which I made reference earlier - namely, coal and iron.

speech.para: Then follow observations, with quotations from official sources, to show the extent of what the writer calls the " slumbering wealth " in the States of Australia. He says-

quote.para: There is hardly a province in the Empire which does not give signs of rich and extensive iron deposits. Australasia is full of it ; in three districts of New South Wales alone it is estimated that there are 13,000,000 tons of ore, containing nearly 0,000,000 tons of metallic iron. Speaking of the Cloncurry district of Queensland, Mr. R. L. Jack, the Government geologist, has said: - "The most striking features of the country are mountains of pure specula and magnetic iron ore. . . It is singular to reflect that these deposits, which, if they were located in England, would be colossal fortunes to their owners, are at present absolutely valueless, owing to their geographical position." In Western Australia, so large is the quantity of iron that it is impossible to work accurately with a magnetic compass. Tasmania's prolific iron deposits ceased to be worked after the discovery in the early seventies that the ore contained chromium, but this assumed defect is now declared, by specialists to be an advantage.

talk.start.para: - The writer of the article is not very much up-to-date. Those iron deposits of which he speaks are at Ilfracombe, in Tasmania, whereas the biggest deposit, perhaps, in the world is at the Blyth River, in that State.
- The writer shows that the presence of chromium, so far from being a disadvantage, is now regarded as an advantage. Speaking of coal, he says -

quote.para: And coal is in equal abundance. Of New South Welsh coal the world is already beginning to hear ; and one runs little risk of exaggeration in saying that the present yearly output of some 0,000,000 tons is the merest scratching of the great body of coal which lies waiting for the piCk in New South Wales. Western Australia, again, gives such encouraging promise of coal that the Government has already found it worth while to construct a railway specially for the purpose' of serving one coal-field.

speech.para: I read these extracts for the purpose of emphasizing the necessity of not, by any diversity of opinion on details, losing this valuable measure. I ask honorable members", whatever they do, not by any inadvertence to lose a measure which will ultimately work to the benefit of all Australia. If we can avoid it, I do not want any money to go out of the Commonwealth to private individuals. I much prefer that any one State should keep in its hands the whole profit arising from its mineral deposits, and I shall do nothing to prevent any State obtaining such benefit, or nothing to place a State in a disadvantageous position as compared with private individuals. But . every State in which there are iron and coal deposits has the power to retain those deposits so far as the land has not already been alienated. Every State has the power to dictate the terms on which its citizen's may work the deposits, and while that power remains, wo run no risk, as a Commonwealth, in seeing that the States have the .same opportunities as are given to private individuals. It is misleading to say that we are going to benefit private individuals. Our great primary object is to benefit the people of the Commonwealth as a whole, and if we can only do that by giving inducements to private enterprise as well as to the States, why should we be deterred from taking that course? Why should we deprive ourselves of great benefits merely because some of our citizens may derive advantage? I hope that, whatever happens, we shall not by any slip or accident prevent the development on this continent of an industry which is the mother of the arts and the source of most of the sciences.

Mr. BROWN(Canobolas).- I hope that the Minister in charge of the Bill has not given his final ultimatum upon the question under consideration. I am glad to know that he is disposed to consider the request that has been submitted to him, and I hope that he will be able to gee his way to consent to the whole of that request which, under the circumstances, is not an unreasonable one. The honorable and learned member for Indi has pointed out the great importance of the iron industry, and the desirableness of doing everything within reason to encourage it. I. agree with him as to its importance, and I am desirous of taking such a course as will permit of its development on lines that I believe will be in the best interests of the Commonwealth. - We have nationalized our railway systems, and the States Governments are the great consumers of iron. Therefore, I hold that it is necessary that the Commonwealth should nationalize the iron industry, and take in hand the work of producing iron from native ores. If the Government simply limit themselves to the mere production of the iron that is required in respect of railways and defence equipment, they will effect a saving in regard to very extensive works. But it is also within the right of the Commonwealth to endeavour to produce iron, not only for its own special requirements, but for general consumption. Therefore when the question of expending the taxpayers' money arises, and one has to choose between granting bonuses for the purpose of assisting private industry and expenditure through State or Federal channels, as the case may be, I prefer to give my support to expenditure under the supervision of the State or Federal Governments. I should prefer to have a proviso in the Bill limiting the bonuses to the States, so that they should not be made available to private enterprise. I should be willing to let that stand until such time as the people of the States indicated through their Governments that they were not prepared as States, to take up the iron industry. Then I should be agreeable to withdraw any opposition I might have offered to private enterprise taking the matter in hand. But the Minister has asked the committee to rescind the decision deliberately arrived at, and has succeeded in carrying what he desired in that respect. The right honorable gentleman cannot, however, shut his eyes to the fact' that with respect, to this matter we have a very strange combination. On the previous occasion vote's were cast against the proposal of the Government with a view of defeating the Bill, and in the hope that it would be dropped. But, as the Government were not prepared to drop their proposals, the ground has been shifted. A number of votes have been recorded for the Government that were cast against them previously. I want to know whether the Minister for Trade and Customs expects those votes to carry him through ? If so, I venture to prophesy that when the next division takes place he will find that some of those honorable members who previously supported him will vote against him. That conclusion is warranted by the tenor of several of the addresses that have been given. Possibly the Minister hopes to counteract the loss of votes in that direction by the support he gains from the labour corner. I want to see the iron industry established under State supervision. But as the proposal which I support has been defeated I have to face the new position that presents itself. At the outset, I ask the Minister whether he is prepared to insert the two . years' proviso I If so, I am willing to support him in his proposal. But, if he insists upon the twelve months' provision, I consider that he will be simply holding out an invitation to the States that will really mean nothing whatever. I will give my reasons for that opinion. The Minister tells us that the States Governments have indicated that they are opposed to undertaking the iron industry. But so far as I can read the communications that have been received, they are really opposed to taking it up at present.

talk.start.para: - They do not qualify in any way ; they hold out no hope.

- The right honorable gentleman says that the States Governments do not qualify their statements in any way-, but the impression conveyed to my mind by the communications was that the States Governments were not prepared to take up the industry at present, and that they preferred to see it taken in hand by private enterprise, and supported by Tariff preferences, as well as by bonuses. But I want to invite the Minister's attention to this phase of the question. The New South Wales Government now has in hand the matter of the expiration of the pastoral leases of the northern division which fell in about a couple of years ago. The question is awaiting legislation in respect to future treatment. That legislation was promised last session, but had to give way to other legislation dealing with the western division of the State, which occupied the greater part of the time. The promise made by the New South Wales Government to the people is that this new comprehensive legislation upon the land question shall be the subject engaging the attention of Parliament for the corning session. It is well known that the land question in New South Wales is very difficult and intricate, that to deal with it requires a whole session, and "that there is great difficulty in compressing its consideration even within the limits of a session. If a State Government takes up that question it practically means that the whole of the time at the disposal of Parliament will be occupied for the coming year. It is customary for Parliament to prorogue about Christmas, and not meet again until about May. How, therefore, can the New South Wales Parliament be expected to take any effective step with. regard to the iron industry within the next twelve months? But if the two years' limit is -fixed it will give the people reasonable time to express -their opinions. Further, I should like to remind the Government that within two years this Parliament will have gone to its masters, who, in the meantime, will hove had an opportunity to say whether those who voted for State enterprise or for private enterprise being assisted in this way meet with public approval. I am prepared to support the two years'" proposal, and what is more, I am prepared to assist the Minister in carrying his measure if it be adopted. I am not in the position of being a false friend to the measure. I undertake to give the Bill my support light through if the Minister accepts this proposal.
- When the honorable member talks of the two years' period, does he mean for the establishment of the industry ?

- No, two years within which a State shall have the right to take the work in hand, and within which to satisfy the Commonwealth Government that it seriously intends to establish the iron industry. If, at the end of two years, the States Governments intimate that they do not intend to pursue-the work, -I am prepared to let it be done by private enterprise. But I want the people of the States to have a fair 01)pm.tunity of saying whether they want the iron industry to be carried on by the States or by private enterprise. For the reasons I have indicated, twelve months is not a sufficient time within which to get an expression of opinion upon this subject from the. people of New South Wales, whilst two years would, I think, be a fairly reasonable time. If the right honorable gentleman insists upon limiting the time to twelve months, I feel that the greater part of that time will have passed away before the State Parliament will have completed the important work Of land legislation at present .pressing upon its attention. Even if it desires seriously to face this question a session in which it can be dealt with cannot be convened before the twelve months is up, and that will be used as an argument against dealing with it at all. All I ask is, that the people of the State shall have a reasonable opportunity to express their wishes on this matter, and that we shall not be tied down to expressions of opinion received from persons who are Premiers today, but who may not be Premiers tomorrow or in a little time hence. If a period of two years is provided for, I shall assist the right honorable gentleman to cany the Bill. But if he refuses that, the position I have to face is whether an insufficient time, like twelve months should induce me to support it, or whether it would be wiser to knock the Bill out and leave it an open question until we can deal with it with a greater amount of information as to the feelings of the people upon the subject than we have at the present time.

speech.para: Mr. HUGHES(West Sydney). - I desire to express my regret that I should have done the right honorable the Minister for Trade and Customs so much injustice as to charge him . with having changed his mind from last Friday. I find that my diatribe in so far as that is concerned was inaccurate and ' uncalled for. I find that it was on Thursday .the .right honorable gentleman expressed the opinion which I said he expressed on Friday. I therefore have to withdraw the -statement I made.

talk.start.para: - I acknowledge the withdrawal of the honorable member, but if he looks into the matter a little more he will find that it is necessary for him to go still further back.

speech.para: Mr. CONROY(Werriwa). - -I should like to know exactly the attitude the Government take upon this amendment. At one minute we are told they are going to agree to it and at the next that they are not. They now appear to be trying to find out from the committee in some mysterious way whether a provision for two years' time can be carried against them or not. Surely Ministers should be able1 to say what they intend to do 1 Is the right honorable gentleman going to stand by his proposal for twelve months? Apparently, if he finds that there is not quit? a sufficient number to carry the proposal for two years, he will urge the proposal for twelve months, and if he finds that there will not be a sufficient number to carry that proposal he will -throw it over also - just as before, when he discovered that he had six votes to the good, he found that no explanation was needed as to why he changed his opinion. I may be discussing a proposal for two years when the Government, in order -to -save appearances, will accept one year eleven months and twenty-seven days. The Minister appears to be quite indifferent as to -the fate of the Bill, provided he can retain the appearance of carrying some measure which will come under the same heading. Honorable members who are supporting this proposal for a two years' preference for the State, argue, first of all, that from the very nature of it the iron industry would be practically a monopoly, and it should not therefore fall into the -hands of private individuals. If it is in the nature of a monopoly, that is no doubt a sound argument in support of the contention that the -States should take it up, but the Minister says that he has certain replies from the State Governments, and that they are not going to deal with it. It is for this reason the light honorable gentleman proposes to hand it over entirely to private individuals. Honorable members ask for a period of preference for the States, and from their point of view I do not think the two years asked for is .too long. It will be some months before any State Parliament can discuss the . subject and decide whether or not it will deal with it. If the State Parliaments decide to deal with it, some months will necessarily elapse before the . undertaking can be got into working order. That is a sufficient reason for asking for a period of two years. There is another argument in 'favour of the proposal in the fact that within the next two years general elections will take place in two or three of the -States, and it may be that a State Parliament which at the present time refuses to deal with this matter will then be ready to deal with it. Another argument may be adduced on -behalf of the Commonwealth Parliament itself. When the Commonwealth is being asked to vote away a very large sum of money -without authority from 'the people and without in any -way .consulting the electors, it is only -right that some care should be exercised. Let honorable members look at the effect upon the men who are engaged in the foundry and machine trades for which iron is the raw material, if the industry falls into the hands of private individuals who determine to make -the most of the monopoly they will have. If the State conducted the industry arguments could be brought to bear to show why the price of the raw material, pig-iron, should be kept as low as possible. In that case other -States would bring arguments to "bear upon the particular State in which the industry was being carried on. They would be able-to point out that in the interests of the men engaged in their machine shops and foundries it was absolutely necessary that their raw material should be-kept as low in price as possible. I can leave it to the committee to say whether, if the industry were in the hands of a private company, those engaged in the trades to which I have referred could go to the company and say, "This iron which you manufacture is the raw material for industries employing twenty men where you only employ one." The answer would-be, " We are established here under an Act of Parliament in which it

I was promised that bonuses to the amount of £250,000 would be paid in connexion with this industry, and that promise must be carried out." I think these people would be entitled to contend that a succeeding Parliament was, to a certain extent, bound by the agreement made. Holding that view, it is perfectly clear that, though I am strongly opposed to the Bill, I must try to insist upon a delay that will give time not only to one person, but to a great many persons to come in and take advantage of its provisions. Let me give another argument which must appeal to those who hold that private enterprise should undertake this work. I cannot but think that two years is not an unreasonable time within which to advertise in the markets of the world an offer of this kind.

talk.start.para: - The honorable and learned member is wasting our time and the time of the country.

- It is far better to take up the time of the country than to take money out of the pockets of the people either to give it to a State or to individuals. If honorable members opposite are fretting because they are not able to get this money for certain people I can understand it.
- I ask whether the honorable and learned member is using language which is in accordance with parliamentary usage, and in order ?

- The honorable and learned member must confine his remarks to the question before the Chair. I must again call the attention of the honorable and learned member to the standing orders, by which he, as well as other honorable members, are bound.
- I can easily put myself in order, sir, as you very well know.
- The honorable and learned member must not use a threat to the Chair.
- Then I move-

speech.para: That the Chairman do now leave the Chair.

talk.start.para: - Under the circumstances, I refuse to accept the motion.
- You must accept it. I insist that you do. That is a threat if you like.
- Will the honorable and learned member resume his seat ?
- Will the Chairman speak in a different tone ?

- I have asked the honorable and learned member on several occasions to confine his remarks to the amendment before the committee. He must do so. If he disobeys my ruling, I shall ask him to discontinue his speech.

- I have my remedy, though I am very loth to avail myself of it. I was not allowed to finish my sentence just now. I was showing how we get here men who, though trained in a study which should quicken their minds and invigorate their understandings-
- The honorable and learned member is repeating his offence.
- It is not an offence. I am perfectly within my rights. That is the ruling I dispute.
- As the honorable and learned member has disobeyed the Chair, I order him to discontinue his speech.
- I move that your ruling be dissented from.
- The honorable and learned member can only move that he be further heard.
- Mr. Chairman-
- Will the honorable and learned member resume his seat? I have no other recourse now but to name the honorable and learned member for disregarding the authority of the Chair.

- I trust that the honorable and learned member for Werriwa will relieve me of the painful duty which otherwise I am called upon by the standing orders to discharge, by apologizing to the Chairman, thus removing the whole cause of the trouble. We must respect the rulings of the Chairman, in whom we have every confidence. The honorable and learned member may consider the ruling a wrong one, but I am sure that he does not suspect either the motives or the impartiality of the Chairman.
- If I did not sit down as rapidly as the Chairman thought I should, it was not from a desire to affront him, either personally or in his official position. I was annoyed at being interrupted.
- Oh !
- I will deal with the Minister in a moment. I am not receiving shares for supporting the Bill. However, I shall not continue the line of argument upon which I was engaged. I moved -

speech.para: That the Chairman do now leave the Chair, and I submit that I was in order. I am perfectly willing to obey the command of the Chairman to resume my seat. I am not aware that any expression fell from my lips which was insulting to the Chairman, but if he mentions anything I said which he considers a reflection upon him, I shall withdraw it.

talk.start.para: - Is the Chairman satisfied?

- It is not for the Chairman alone to be satisfied, but for the committee. I put it to the committee that as the honorable and learned member has apologized, the naming should be withdrawn. There being no expression of dissent, I withdraw it.

- I do not wish to unduly prolong the debate, but there is a principle involved in the action of the Minister for Trade and Customs this afternoon which does not commend itself to my political intelligence, and I therefore, wish to say a few words on the matter. On a former occasion the honorable member for Bland carried an amendment restricting the granting of bonuses to the Governments of States, and this afternoon, after a debate which has extended over some days, the Minister succeeded in rescinding that amendment. Now, however, we are asked to consider another amendment which, though different from, is very similar to the proviso which has just been struck out, and the Minister has swung round as quickly as a gale at sea, and proposes to accept what the committee thought they had decided, when agreeing to his amendment this afternoon, not to accept. How am I, in this chaotic presentment of circumstances, to exercise my intelligence and experience on behalf of my constituents and my country ? It must be remembered that this is not a Parliament of a State, but a. much higher political body. The kernel of what I desire to speak about - the lack of party cohesion and party sympathy - has been the subject of former speeches. Honorable members will remember that I have before called attention to the absence of caucuses. I ask Ministers if there has ever been a caucus held by the party which is keeping the Government in office? Not the ghost of one.
- They think that all they have to do is to crack the whip and the party will respond.

- I am the quietest member of this House, but my political vitality and instincts rise in rebellion against what has taken place in this chamber within the last few hours. The action of the Minister is an outrage upon those who have consistently supported them in power.
- The honorable and learned member should have listened to the Minister's speech onFriday.

- I did listen to it, and though I have always listened to his speeches with pleasure, I say that this is not a question of speech-making. A great principle is involved. The Ministry ask us now to vote for what they were originally opposed to, and therefore I think it is about time that some of us retired from our present position, as supporters of the Government. We have given the Ministry consistent support, and have very frequently abstained from expressing our opinions in order to facilitate business, and many of us find it difficult to comprehend the action of the Government in ignoring the existence of their followers. A spirit of tyranny exists amongst Ministers worse than that which characterized the Csars. The Emperors of Rome did take some of their supporters into their counsels, but the Ministry treat their followers with scorn.

- The amendment proposed by the honorable member for Kennedy affords me an opportunity to place myself in the position which I have desired to occupy from the outset. As I intimated in my speech upon the second reading of this Bill, I am not in accord with those free-traders who consistently oppose bonuses. I believe that they offer the best means of affording assistance to the iron industry, but I am afraid that we may ultimately find that we shall have to pay too dearly for our whistle, in the shape of the further protection that it may be necessary to extend to the industry. The amendment will meet my views far more closely than did the proposal of the honorable member for Bland, under which private enterprise would have been entirely blocked. I do not agree with those free-traders who are opposed to all forms of State enterprise of this character, nor do I think that the position they assume is an entirely logical one. One honorable member contended that the State administration of the railways had not been entirely successful, even under railway commissioners. I think, however, that the railways in some of the States have been very successfully managed indeed ; and so far as tramway management is concerned, I think that any comparison between the private and State-owned systems in operation in Melbourne and Sydney respectively must result in favour of the latter. No tramway enterprise in Australia has been so successful as that of Sydney.
- The Sydney tramways return only 3.56 per cent. upon the capital outlay.

- The honorable member seems to think that the Sydney tramways are not successful because they only return 3.56 per cent., but he must admit that they give the cheapest and best travelling facilities in Australia.
- That is not correct.

- It is in the character of the facilities afforded to the travelling public that the public of Sydney derive the full benefit. If the tramways return more than sufficient to pay the interest on the money borrowed for their construction, and afford cheap travelling facilities, and tend to improve the value of suburban properties, they must be regarded as successful.
- There is no analogy between providing travelling facilities and establishing the iron industry.

- It is rather late in the day to debate the abstract question of State versus private enterprise. I firmly believe that the whole world is progressing in the direction of the State control of all works of general utility, and I do not regret that this principle is being extended, because so long as we develop in that direction slowly enough, no danger need be apprehended. The manufacture of the iron is an enterprise upon which the State Government might fairly embark. Up to the present time, private capitalists have not entered upon it, and as we all wish to see it established, we might legitimately trust the States to undertake it. By adopting the amendment proposed by the honorable member for Kennedy, we shall, I believe do good in all directions, and I cannot see why the Government should oppose it. The Minister has told us that he has no objection to the States entering upon this industry, and his only reply , to those who were content to leave the matter to the States was that the States Governments had intimated that there was no immediate probability of their taking the matter up. Upon this ground, and no other, he declined to restrict the enterprise to State control. It must be admitted, however, that the replies of certain Premiers who hold office at present cannot be taken to represent the voice of the people. If we allow the States two years in which to make up their minds, we can settle the question of whether the people desire that another socialistic experiment shall be made, or that the establishment of ironworks shall be left to private enterprise. To that extent we are bound to consult the people in each of the States. The honorable and learned member for Parkes suggested that some constitutional difficulty might arise if we granted bonuses to certain States and taxed others in order to provide the necessary money. I protested at one time against the imposition of customs duties that were not intended for revenue, but for purely protective purposes, as being opposed to the spirit of the Constitution. The bonuses now proposed are nothing but the converse of the protective duties provided for in the Tariff ; and if it is wrong to tax the people of one State in order to secure the establishment of the manufactures in another, it must be equally wrong to impose protective duties upon all the States for the benefit of the manufacturers of Victoria. Another advantage of the proposal which we are now considering is, that if we allow the States two years within which to decide whether they will embark upon the manufacture of iron, we shall probably not be called upon to provide the funds necessary for the bonuses for at least another year. This delay will enable us to make more suitable financial arrangements than would otherwise be possible. The Government have supplied us with no data upon which we can determine whether the circumstances of the Commonwealth will enable us to pay these large bonuses. At any rate we might well defer the consideration of this measure for one or two years. I cannot understand how, in the light of his previous utterances, the right honorable gentleman in charge of the Bill can oppose an amendment in the direction of placing the iron industry under State control. If he is sincere in this matter he will surely agree to allow a reasonable time to. elapse within which pressure can be brought to bear upon the States' Governments to induce them to take up this work. If they still decline to do so, our position will then be no worse, and we shall be able to consider this Bill with a much better knowledge of the facts than we have at present.

- I think that I am entitled to say another word or two for a variety of reasons, one of which is the interest that I have taken in this Bill from first to last, and which I do not think any honorable member will venture to dispute. I have done what I could for the purpose of making the position of the Government as clear as is the noonday sun. Any honorable member who has been in the Chamber during the debates upon this question must agree that we left no room for doubt that above all things we desired to witness the early establishment of the iron industry. That was the chief object which we had in view. We did not fail to indicate that we should prefer to see the industry established by a State on behalf of all its people rather than by any company, which, however large, could not hope to rival the State industry in extent or in the area over which the benefits of the concession would be distributed. Does any honorable member suggest that we did not speak plainly in that connexion ? I know nothing which I have omitted to do, and which could have been done, to insure the successful passing of the Bill upon those lines. I ask the honorable member for South Sydney - and I do not speak in the slightest degree with intent to leave any cause for regret - what is his position in regard to this matter? To-day he practically reproaches us with the fact that the Bill is not in the best shape. That is the reproach which he ventures to cast upon the Government of the day. I tell him that it is not our fault; it is his. We proposed the very thing which to-day he advocates, and in each instance he voted against it. Here it is recorded in black and white, on the 19th of June, page 13941 of Hansard. Upon the division which took place as to whether a preference of two years should be given to the States to undertake the work if they so pleased, the Government supporting it and doing all they could for the purpose of carrying it, we find it recorded that the vote of the honorable member for South Sydney was cast against us.
- That is right.
