- Of course, it is right as a quotation, but is it right when the honorable member rises in his place and reproaches us - as he has done to-night - for not moving in a certain direction? I say that the fault, at least, is his. We tried to do so weeks ago, and he did his best for the purpose of preventing our desires from being carried out. Similarly as regards the question of confining the Bill to the States. We voted against that proposal, and he voted in favour of it. Under such circumstances, how does it lie in his mouth to reproach us. The honorable and learned member for Brisbane has said that the Government have turned round, and that he cannot conceive of any reason for it. Of course he cannot if he is absent from the Chamber and does not know what is going on. We have not held caucuses, and I do not know that I believe in them.
- The Government are not going bo tyrannise over me.

- We have no desire to tyrannise. We believe that open debate is in many respects preferable to secret caucuses, and we plead guilty to the fact that we have not held caucuses of the character to which he referred.
-but the Minister has written to honorable members asking them to support him upon this measure.

-Why should I not do so ? Does that act constitute a caucus ? If a Minister is to be refused the liberty of writing to Government supporters calling their attention to arguments in favour of any Bill, we have arrived at a pretty state of things. But I do not think that time has come yet. As regards the statement of the honorable and learned member for Brisbane that he never heard of our proposal to restrict priority to the States to a period of years, I wish to say that we attempted to give effect to it in this House two or three weeks ago.
- And abandoned it.

- We did not abandon it ; we were beaten. As regards those who are really interested in this industry' I sympathize deeply with the remarks of the honorable and learned member for Indi. I put it again - "Let us be careful that we do not, upon a matter of detail, Split those who are in favour of the cause, and lose that which we desire to see carried out." No doubt there are various ways of injuring a Bill. We have had instances in this Chamber of honorable members voting upon the same side when there has been absolutely no sympathy between them in the attainment of a common object. There are members who voted to confine the object of the Bill to the States, but who had not the slightest desire to see it carried.
- Now the Minister wishes to use those votes to defeat the decision of the committee.
- I desire to use them to prevent the Bill from being made a farce.
- Did not the Minister promise that he would put the Bill through upon the lines of the amendment proposed by the honorable member for Bland?
- I did.
- Now the right honorable gentleman reverses his decision.

- Yes, when I find that there is no reasonable prospect of the States embarking upon the industry at an early date. When the facts are not found to be as I fondly hoped they would, I should be worse than a dolt if I did not, to some extent, alter my attitude to meet the newly-revealed condition of affairs. The Government have given a reason for their actions, and the committee, I am happy to say, have supported them. Ought we now upon a mere matter of detail - the question of the period within which the States must avail themselves of the privileges conferred by the Bill - to risk losing it altogether ? I hope we shall not be guilty of any such egregious folly, and I do ask honorable members who really desire to see the enterprise undertaken - preferably by the States, but who wish to see it established in any circumstances - not to lend themselves to the wishes of those who have no sympathy with the measure before us.

speech.para: Mr. McDONALD(Kennedy).- Throughout his remarks the right honorable gentleman has not told the committee what are his intentions.

talk.start.para: - I said before the adjournment for dinner that I intended to oppose giving the States two years' priority, but was willing to consent to granting them one year.
- The Minister is therefore going back upon his original proposal. When he is prepared to accept one year, why cannot he lay the Bill aside until next session.
- The honorable member is entirely opposed to the Bill.
- I am opposed to allowing any one to embark upon the enterprise other than the States. The right honorable gentleman told us that he would rather see the States undertake the work.
- I said so, and I do not want to qualify my statement one bit.

- The right honorable gentleman endeavours to qualify a good many of his remarks. He says he believes in the States undertaking this work, and adds a " but," which nullifies all his previously expressed opinions. He has been so anxious to get this measure through - for what reason I do not know - that he has actually gone to the trouble of writing to a number of honorable members, asking them to support it.

talker.party: FT; ANTI-SOC from 1906; LP from 1910; NAT from 1917
talker.name: SMITH, Arthur
Mr BRUCE SMITH

talk.start.para: - Did he send a printed circular ?
- No, I saw a communication in his own handwriting, asking an honorable member to support this Bill.
- Who are the men ? Out with the names.
- The right honorable gentleman does not deny it. A few moments ago he said that he did not believe in secret caucuses.
- Out with it - to whom did I write? Was it not to Mr. Watkins?
- That is one, is it?
- Why should he not write to them ?
- Who are the others ?
- The right honorable gentleman knows to whom he wrote. I do not object to his writing to them.
- The honorable member is endeavouring to make something out of it. Let him show me that I wrote to any one whom I had not the right to address in terms of the greatest friendship.

- I only wish to show how anxious the right honorable gentleman is to carry this Bill in its original form. Yet when the amendment of the honorable member for Bland was carried, he asked honorable members to assist him in passing the measure in that form, so as to give a knock-out blow to those who had opposed it. Personally, I was agreeable to do that. But there has been a change of front on the part of the Minister, from what cause I do not know. Perhaps it is due to the fact; - as was pointed out by the honorable and learned member for Werriwa - that some of the newspapers have been successful in influencing certain members to reverse their previous votes. What I complain of is the twisting and turning about on the part of the Minister. Such conduct is being carried so far that we do not know from hour to hour what the Government policy is.
- I must ask the honorable member not to pursue that line of argument further.

- I hope the amendment will be carried and that honorable members will not allow themselves to be whipped into line for the sake of certain people who specially desire this concession. I understand that if the amendment is carried it may interfere with certain individuals who have almost floated companies to carry on this industry.

speech.para: Mr.Brucesmith. - Floated them in their own interest.

talk.start.para: - I do not object to people floating companies in their own interest; probably I should do the same if I were in their position. But it is not a proper thing to do ; and the passing of the Bill at the present moment will only assist those people to float their companies to greater advantage. If a company had been formed, and were prepared to carry on the industry straight away, I do not know that I should have objected so strongly ; but neither the Federal Government nor the States Governments ought to grant concessions to assist people in floating companies to greater advantage. I gave a fair illustration the other night, which I think can be borne out by the honorable member for Melbourne. The Chillagoe concession was the means of enabling certain individuals in Melbourne to make a considerable amount of money, leaving the " baby to be nursed " by others. The Chillagoe syndicate could not have made the thousands of pounds they did had it not been for the concessions from the Government, and similar results will follow the granting of the concession now proposed.

- It is abominable to have suggestions made in regard to letters written by Ministers to honorable members, and I cannot understand why such allusions should be made by the honorable member for Kennedy. Surely Ministers have a right to communicate with whom they please. Does the honorable member suggest that the letters were such as ought not to have been written ? References of the kind should not be made unless the documents are produced and some charge formulated. I have written to honorable members, amongst them the honorable member for Newcastle and the honorable member for Bland.

speech.para: Mr.Watson. - The Minister did write to me, but there was nothing in the letter to which anybody could object.

talk.start.para: - I am not objecting to the contents of the letters.

- Then, why should the honorable member talk about the letters? These references are indulged in with the object of strengthening the case of the honorable member, and of throwing dirt at the Government, and if they mean anything they mean a suggestion of infamy, which no man worthy to be called a man ought to make unless he is prepared to produce the letters and sheet home a charge. The reason the honorable member has not made a charge is that he cannot do so. I never held conversations with honorable members, or wrote letters of which I have reason to be ashamed ; and it is too bad that such conduct should be indulged in for the purpose of discrediting Ministers.

speech.para: Mr. McDONALD(Kennedy).- I am rather surprised at the heat shown by the Minister. There is probably more in the letters than honorable members seem to think.

talk.start.para: - Produce the letter of which you spoke.
- I have not the letter.
- Then let any honorable member who has the letter produce it.
- I did not refer to either of the two honorable members who have been mentioned.
- Who was it ?
- I shall not tell the right honorable gentleman. When I said that these letters had been written, I did not impute any motive to the Minister.
- Then why mention the letters?
- I said that the right honorable gentleman was very anxious to get this measure through.
- I have shown that anxiety in the House.
- And as evidence of that anxiety I said that the Minister had written letters to certain honorable members, and I mentioned the case of which I had knowledge.
- The honorable member means a lot more, but he has not the pluck to say what he means.

- There is no need for the right honorable gentleman to get so heated. I should not have mentioned the letters had the Minister not said he did not believe in secret caucus meetings. It was then I asked about the writing of the letters, which I regard as equal to the holding of any secret meeting.
- Who was the honorable member to whom I wrote ?

- I shall not satisfy the Minister's curiosity. As to manliness, when I do anything of an unmanly character 1 ask the right honorable gentleman to remind me of it. I do not propose to take lessons in manliness from him.
- It is not that the honorable member does not need them.
- That may be so. There are some people who need lessons and know it, and others who equally need them but do not know it. Amongst the latter is probably the right honorable gentleman.
- I think this has gone far enough.

division.header.para: Question - That the words proposed to be added be so added - put. The committee divided.

division.result.para: Question so resolved in the negative.

division.para: Mr. WATSON(Bland). - I understood the Minister to say that he would insert some words providing for a period of twelve months.

talk.start.para: - What I said, plainly, was that if honorable members would accept a period of twelve months, I would make a proposal to that effect.
- What does that mean ?
- There was some dispute as to what we should do. A. proposal was made for a period of two years, and I offered to make it twelve months, but the offer was not accepted.
- I did not understand the Minister to say what he has just indicated.
- I think the honorable member heard what I said.

- I understood that the Minister was going to be consistent with the attitude he took up on Friday. He is reported in the proofs of Hansard, which have not yet been published, as saying that he intended to give the States a prior opportunity to take up the iron industry. Now he puts it forward that that statement was merely an offer of a compromise as against the two years proposal. I certainly did not understand it as. such, and I do not know that any other honorable member did. If the Minister has become alarmed at the probable defection of some of his more prominent conservative supporters, it is a different matter, but my impression was that he would give the committee an opportunity of voting for twelve months as the time within which the States could take up the proposal. Further than that he emphasized that view. I think I remember the right honorable gentleman saying that he would support a proposal for giving the States a twelve months option.
- If so, he could have moved an amendment.

- The proposal could have been made either as an addendum to the clause or as a new clause. The committee should have an. opportunity of voting on the suggestion the Minister put forward. I do not think twelve months is sufficient time to enable the people of the States to: be consulted on the matter, and to express their opinion clearly and distinctly. If the Bill is to go through, I prefer some such restriction as will give the people time to turn round sooner than have the Bill passed in its present shape. It is due to the committee that the Government should express clearly what they meant a little while ago.

- There seems to be a little warmth whenever we come to a question of recollection. Therefore, it would be well to defer the further consideration of the Bill for the present. Under the circumstances it would be better to report progress, and ask leave to sit again.

. - When we last dealt with the Electoral Bill last week, I said that I would submit the whole measure to a careful examination, so as to make it as complete as possible before it left this Chamber to be returned to the Senate. I have gone through the whole Bill with the Parliamentary Draftsman, and I shall have to move a good many amendments, which are, for the most part, more technical than otherwise, though one or two are of importance. The course I propose to take is to go into committee again for the reconsideration of the clauses in which amendments have to be made. I do not think this reconsideration will occupy much time. I move -

speech.para: That the Bill he recommitted to a Committee of the whole House for the reconsideration of clauses 33, 47, 80, 98a, 90, . 105, 114, 114b, 130, 146, 173, 174, 178, 197, 197a,197e, 197f, 197q, Forms K, M, N, Q, and R, and new clause 19a.

talk.start.para: - I wish to have a few other clauses recommitted for the purpose of assisting the Minister. I desire to have the Bill made as perfect as possible. I move-

speech.para: That clauses108,142,164, 165,197,213, and Form G be also recommitted.
Mr. BATCHELOR(South Australia).I move -
That clauses 43 and 74 and Form P be also recommitted.

talk.start.para: - The amendments to be proposed by the Minister have not been circulated for a sufficient period to give honorable members an opportunity of seeing whether they cover all the objections to the Bill. I am under the impression that the Bill requires two new schedules. I understand that there is no schedule providing for the issue of writs by either the Speaker or the President of the Senate. The Constitution provides that, at certain times writs may be issued by either the President or the Speaker, and there needs to be a form for the purpose. I understand also that by certain powers we are proposing to take under this Bill, we are usurping State rights in connexion with elections in certain cases. I do not know whether the honorable member for South Australia, Mr. Glynn, has included the clauses raising that question.
-It will be raised on schedule G.

- This is not the first occasion on which this kind of thing has occurred, and I think it is very objectionable to introduce amendments without giving honorable members a sufficient time for their consideration before the Bill is recommitted to deal with them. As so very few honorable members really know what clauses ought to be recommitted, I suggest that it would be better that the whole Bill should be recommitted.
- If there is found to be anything special to do, it will be easy to further recommit before the Bill leaves the Chamber.
-With that assurance, I shall not raise any further objection.

- I point out to the Minister that there was an amendment made in clause 8 permitting a polling place to be outside of an electorate. This was done for reasons which I gave before that amendment was accepted, and I understood that the Bill was to be brought into conformity with it. The clauses which the Minister proposes to recommit do not cover the clauses which require to be verbally amended in consequence of the amendment made in clause 8. Does the honorable gentleman wish that I should move the recommittal of those clauses?

- It is stated to me by the draftsman that clause 26, where the word " for " is used, gives the necessary power to carry out the honorable member's proposal, and that is the reason I have not asked that the clauses to which he has referred should be recommitted.
- I am willing to accept that if in committee it is found to be the case, but in the meantime I had better move the recommittal of the half-dozen clauses affected.
- If there is found to be any doubt about it, I shall not let the Bill go without dealing with the matter.
- The trouble is that I cannot call attention to these clauses in committee unless they are recommitted. I therefore move: -

speech.para: That clauses 7, 9, 27, 106, 140a, JOI, and .172 be also recommitted.

talk.start.para: . - If the matter with which the honorable member desires to deal has reference to the proposal to vote for an electorate instead of in an electorate, I can assure him that it is provided for. If the honorable member will look at clause 26 he will see that the expression " for an electorate " is used. Under that clause it will be possible to appoint such polling places for each division as may be considered to be necessary.
- Yes ; but there are other clauses which require to be consequentially amended.
- I should like to see them before passing an opinion, but am under the impression that clause 26 is ample to cover all the honorable member desires there.

speech.para: Mr. SYDNEYSMITH (Macquarie).The Minister in charge of the Bill promised to recommit clause lol, relating to voting for the Senate.

talk.start.para: - No. We had a full debate upon that extending over hours.

- If the honorable member cares to look . up Hansard, he will find that the Minister promised the honorable member for Werriwa' that the clause would be recommitted. The matter was decided in a very small House. I move -

speech.para: That clauses .151 and 152 be also recommitted.

talk.start.para: - I trust the House will not agree to recommit clause 151. We debated the question as to how electors should vote for the Senate . during almost a whole day. We finally came to a decision one way, and now the honorable member desires to go into the whole ' question again. It is quite fair to recommit clauses in connexion with which some matter may have slipped through, or where some necessary consequential amendment has to be considered, but I see no wisdom in going over the whole ground of the Electoral Bill again. I might with just as much reason ask the House to recommit the clauses dealing with voting by post. It is not fair to recommit clauses involving large questions of principle which have been debated hour after hour, and I shall divide the House on the proposal to recommit clause 151.

speech.para: Question - That the Bill be recommitted to a committee of the whole House for the reconsideration of clauses 7, 9, 27, 33, 43, 47, '74, SO, 98a, 99, 105, 106, 108, 114,, 114b, 130, 140a, 142, 146, 152, 161, 164, 165, 172, 173, 174, 178, 197, 197a, 197e, 197f, 197q, 213, Forms G, K, M, N, P, Q, and R of the Schedule, and for the reconsideration of new clause 19a - resolved in the affirmative.

talk.start.para: - I pointed, out that the Government have already agreed to recommit clause 151, and I trust that the proposal will be' agreed to .without a division. The question was decided when there was not a full attendance of members present, and in this democratic country what we are anxious to do is to ascertain the wishes of the representatives of the people, when there is a full attendance of members present. If the full sense of the committee had been . taken upon this matter I should not urge its reconsideration. I understand that many honorable members are anxious that the question should come before them again, and I hope an opportunity will be afforded honorable members in a full House to say what they really think upon the subject.
- It is rather an unusual course for the honorable member for-Bland to object to the recommittal of this clause when the Government have given their sanction to its recommittal.
- What I said was that I should not oppose it.

- When the Minister in charge of a Bill says that he will not oppose the recommittal of a clause, it means that, so far as he is concerned, he agrees to its recommittal. I do not anticipate that there will be any long debate upon the subject if the clause is recommitted. Of course the honorable member for Bland will be quite within his right in insisting upon a vote ; but it will be very curious treatment of the honorable member for Macquarie if there is any opposition to the recommittal of the clause.

- If there is to be no debate upon the matter when the clause is recommitted, we might as well take the division now. If honorable members cannot carry the recommittal of the clause, they will not be able to carry the amendment they desire to make. I do not altogether object to the recommittal, but it is not wise to recommit clauses merely for the purpose of further discussion when there is no possible hope that any amendment of them will be carried. If there is not some probability of the previous decision arrived at being reversed, we might just as well refuse to recommit the clause.

speech.para: Mr. BATCHELOR(South Australia).I join with the honorable member for Bland in objecting altogether to the recommittal of this clause. It involves a matter of principle which was debated here for a whole day. A final decision was arrived at upon it after one of the most exhaustive discussions which have taken place on this Bill. There was a good attendance of members present, and even a much better attendance than usual, and all the votes were accounted for. I ask whether there is going to be any finality to the discussion of this Bill? I feel as strongly about some matters upon which I and those who think with me were defeated, as honorable members can feel about this clause, but I do not ask for the recommittal of the clauses in which I am concerned. I think we ought not to be continually debating matters of principle which have been previously discussed and decided, in the hope that some honorable member will change his mind.

talk.start.para: - In my opinion, the whole Bill should be recommitted if it is thought desirable to recommit clauses which have been fully discussed and dealt with, as this has. The only clauses which should be recommitted are those upon which finality was not reached at a previous stage, and in regard to which the Minister promised to bring down further proposals. I shall oppose the recommital, in the interests of despatch.

Clause 33 (Persons entitled to have their names on roll).

talk.start.para: . - I move -

speech.para: That the following words be added, " Provided that any senator or member of the House of Representatives shall, if he so desires, he entitled to have his name placed on and retained on the roll for the division in which he lived at the time of his election instead of the roll for the division in which he lives."

This proviso is added so that the names of members of this Parliament who are compelled, in the performance of their duties, to live where it is in the habit of meeting, may not have their names struck off the rolls for the divisions which they represent. Some honorable members who live in Melbourne have already been threatened with that penalty.

talk.start.para: - The need of this proviso has been brought about by the use of the word " lives," throughout the Bill, in place of the word "resides."
- No ; the reason for it arose before the Bill was framed.

- The word " resides " has a very different meaning from the word " lives." A Judge would hesitate to say that a member resided in Melbourne, although he might live here. The Minister, by this proviso, is giving members of this Parliament the option of having their names enrolled either in Melbourne or for a division in another State. I appeal to him to substitute the word "resides" for the word " lives" throughout both this Bill and the Franchise Act. The word "lives" is not used in any Electoral Act with which I am acquainted.

- I am in sympathy with the purpose of the amendment, but I should like to know how it will work. It will, of course, not affect the State electoral rolls, but suppose that a member representing one of the divisions of Sydney took a house in Melbourne and lived here, how would he meet the requirements of the nomination paper in regard to the matter of residence ? I take it that he would have to say that he resided in Melbourne, whereas his qualification would be his enrolment in Sydney.
- Yes, but a member's name might be struck off the roll for the division in which he formerly resided.
- Even if that happened he could have himself enrolled in Melbourne for the division in which he resided.

speech.para: Mr.HenryWillis. - Not unless he made application to be enrolled.

talk.start.para: - Of course, he would have to apply to be enrolled. If a Member of Parliament will not take the trouble involved in making such an application, how can we expect other people to do so? I take it that under this Bill, enrolment anywhere within the Commonwealth will allow a candidate to be nominated. Supposing that, whilst living in Adelaide, I preferred to allow my name to remain on the roll for the Lang division in Sydney?
- The honorable member could do that if he chose. The clause will not place any honorable member at a disadvantage.

- I do not know whether this clause will operate exactly as the Minister desires. For the first Parliament there will be no difficulty. If a member from Queensland came to live in Melbourne, would he have the right on being re-elected to retain his name on the roll of the division which he represents ?
- Yes.

- There will be many cases such as I have mentioned, but those honorable members whose rights we specially desire to conserve will derive little or no benefit from this clause. What we desire to do is to allow a member to retain his connexion with the electorate he represents, and I see no other course open than to provide that a member of the House of Representatives shall be entitled to have his name retained upon the roll of the electorate which he represents, whilst a senator shall have a similar right in regard to his State.

- It is very necessary that some provision of this kind should be made. My own case is no doubt similar to that of many other honorable members. I do not quite know where my home is. I regard as my home the electorate I represent, because there lie all my interests outside of politics. I find it necessary to travel to Sydney every week. Thus I spend three days of every week in Melbourne, two days in the train, and two days in Sydney, and I am very seldom at home. In New South Wales the point has been raised that a man's domicile is the place where his wife resides, whilst on the other hand it has been held that the wife's domicile is where her husband lives. If the place where a man's wife resides is to be regarded as his domicile, it will be necessary for some members of this Chamber to change their residence every month, if not every week. I am entirely in sympathy with the object of the amendment, because in the absence of some such provision a great deal of confusion and difficulty will arise.

- In order to meet the objections which have been raised, I desire to omit the word "the "before the word " division," with a view to insert the word "any," and to omit the words "in which he lived at the time of his election " with a view to insert the words " he represents."

speech.para: Amendment amended accordingly.

talk.start.para: - I do not think that the clause, as at present drafted, will meet the case of senators.
- The word " any " is designed to do that.
- Still, I do not think that the clause is drafted in the most satisfactory form.

speech.para: Mr. GLYNN(South Australia).- The alterations just made partly remove the objections to the amendment, but, even now, it will not meet the case of the honorable member for Barrier. In order to carry out the object of the Minister we should provide that a senator or member of the House of Representatives should not, unless he so elected, be deemed by residence incidental to attendance at Parliament to have changed his place of living.
Amendment agreed to.

No person who is or within fourteen days after the issue of the writ has been a Member of the Parliament of a State shall be capable of being nominated as a senator, or as a member of the House of Representatives.
Amendment (by Sir William Lyne) proposed -

That the words "or within fourteen days after the issue of the writ has been " be omitted with a view to insert in lieu thereof the words " at the date of the nomination or who was at any time within fourteen days prior to the date of nomination."

talk.start.para: - I hope that the Minister will not persist in the amendment. When this was previously under discussion, it did not receive that consideration which its importance warrants. To my mind, it savours of an aggressive piece of legislation which is altogether unworthy of this Parliament. The proposal was put forward upon the ground that some of the States had enacted a similar provision in respect of Members of this Parliament.
- Is it fair to discuss the question after the debate we. had upon it the other night ?
- It was not debated to any great extent.
- The majority was so great that the. minority would not call for a division.
- The clause not only imposes an improper embargo upon Members of the State Parliaments, but also limits the choice of the electors, and therefore I protest against it.
- I do not intend to debate this clause, although

speech.para: I quite agree that it is necessary to make clear to the outside public the way in which honorable members view it. Despite the fact that I opposed the provision to disqualify Members of State Parliaments from election to the Federal Parliament, I find that my action was completely misrepresented in South Australia. It was said that myself and others supported this provision for the purpose of protecting our own interests. I think that the clause should be struck out. We ought not to copy the very bad example set by some of the States.

When the clause was before the committee on a previous occasion it went through without challenge, owing to some misunderstanding. Clause 152 (Contingent Vote) -

Mr. SYDNEYSMITH (Macquarie).In view of the attitude taken up by the Government in connexion with the previous clause, it is my intention to move an amendment upon this clause which will raise the whole question, and I therefore ask the Minister to agree to adjourn now, because there will be a debate upon the question. I desire to get an expression of opinion upon a matter which has not so far been fairly dealt with. I do not impute motives to any honorable members, but the vote previously taken upon the amendment moved in clause 151 was decided by sixteen to nineteen, and there were several pairs, in which the names of members were given for the amendment by mistake. I move: -
That the words " In the case of the Senate the voters shall vote for the full number of candidates to be elected, and " be inserted at the commencement of the clause.

What I propose was provided for in clause 151, as originally introduced by the Government, and it was only defeated by three votes in a thin House. I do not propose to debate the question at length, but I leave honorable members to test the question by a division upon the amendment.

talk.start.para: - There can be very little doubt that the better place in which to have inserted this amendment was at the end of clause 151, where it stood in the Bill as originally introduced by the Government. The clause, as originally introduced, was carried against the Government by a vote of nineteen to sixteen, and, including pairs, only 47 members voted, leaving 28 members of the House unaccounted for in the division. It is also asserted that at least two or three honorable members, who were prepared to support the clause as it originally stood, were wrongly paired upon this question of plumping. The Government have been asked to recommit the clause that there might be an opportunity given to get an expression of opinion on the subject in a full House. I submit to the Minister in charge of the Bill that at 1 1 o'clock it is hardly fair to go on with the consideration of this subject. This is a very important question, and it was previously decided by 35 members actually voting, and when there were 40 members absent. If a vote had been taken on the question in a full House I should not object. I think it not an unreasonable request to ask that we should adjourn, because I confess that if we took a vote upon the amendment now there would be a great many members absent. I do not think that there should be any plumping for the Senate. While we are perfectly within our rights in arranging the details of elections for the Senate, I doubt the propriety of amending a provision which has already been agreed toby that body. In my opinion, electors should be compelled to vote for the full number of candidates to be elected, and the majority should rule. A provision which will allow plumping will provide for the introduction of all the evils of what is known as the machine system of politics, and then it will be good-bye to fair representation.

speech.para: Mr. SYDNEYSMITH (Macquarie).I am strongly of opinion that a division should not be taken upon this question tonight. When it was last dealt with, only 34 members out of a House of 75 voted upon it. It may be said that honorable members should not be absent, but it must not be forgotten that the hour is very late, and that many of us were travelling all last night.

talk.start.para: - The honorable member promised that if I would recommit the clause it should not be debated at any length.
- I do not wish to hear a long discussion, but I do not think a division should be taken until to-morrow?
- Why not ? Are the numbers up?
-Whatever may be the result, I desire to see a fair vote upon the question.
- Honorable members knew hours ago that the clause was to be dealt with to-night.
- It is only two hours since the Bill was recommitted.
- Although the official report of debates in committee is a condensed one, the discussion of this clause occupies fifteen pages ofHansard.
- However much the question may have been debated already, I think that I am not unreasonable in asking that the division be taken to-morrow.
- I shall never again believe the honorable member's promises.
- I have not repudiated any promise, though the Minister endeavoured to repudiate his promise to recommit the clause.
- It was a pure oversight.

- The right honorable member for Tasmania has suggested a compromise, and I think the committee should have a fair opportunity of dealing with it when there is a good attendance of members. I think that the electors may be reasonably asked to select six or three candidates, as the case may be, as the best men to represent them.
- That is all we want.

- No ; the honorable member wishes that the electors shall vote for one or more candidates just as they think fit. But I desire that the electors shall express their opinion regarding a sufficient number of candidates to fill the vacant seats.
- An elector may have no opinion with regard to more than one of the candidates.

- Then he will have himself to blame for not having secured the nomination of a sufficient number of candidates to represent his views. It is not likely that there will be any scarcity of candidate!). 1" hope that the Government will consent to a postponement, because I am sure that little if any time will be taken up in debating the matter tomorrow.

- As the last trains leave at 11.30 p.m., the honorable member for Macquarie . has the satisfaction of knowing that he has accomplished the object which he had in view. Under the circumstances I am compelled to report progress. I did not 'anticipate when T agreed to the recommittal of the Bill that I should be placed in the position which I now occupy by the honorable member. A promise was given that there would be no debate. I have been caught once-
- I object to the Minister making any insinuations whatever. My position is straighter than is his own. His actions have always been as crooked as a <4©g'8 hind leg.
- The honorable member must know that he has offended against the standing orders, and I ask him to withdraw the remark which he has just made.
- If you, sir, .would coll the Minister to order when he attacks me, there would lie no necessity for me to reply to his statements. I have .just as much right to the courtesy of debate as he has.

- I am sorry that the honorable member for Macquarie should become so heated over this question. I had hoped that the committee would dispose pf this Bill to-night in order that we might deal with fresh business to-morrow, but under the circumstances I shall report progress;

speech.para: Progress reported.
